. I am the wife of
Robert Purser
, a pawnbroker , of Limehouse-causeway
. This gown was pawned with us by Thomas, on the 13th of December for 3s., and on the 24th of December she sent a boy for it - the prisoner was in the shop at the time, redeeming something, and the boy put the things all on the counter together - she had left the shop about an hour before Thomas' gown was missed; Wiggins brought it to our shop on the 15th of March - I only knew the prisoner as a customer.

EDWARD WILLIAM
WIGGINS. I am foreman to Mr. Dakers, of Limehouse. On the 14th of March the prisoner pawned this gown for 2s. 6d. - I saw her at the Police-station next day.
ANN THOMAS. This is my gown - I had pawned it at Purser's; on the 24th of December I sent my boy to redeem it; he returned without it.
HENRY LEE. I am a Policeman. I apprehended the prisoner at the Steam Washing Company's premises, Millwall - she said she had bought the gown in Salmon-lane.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that she had bought the gown.

GUILTY . Aged 48. -
Confined One Month .

915.
JOHN HILL
,
MICHAEL ARTHUR
, and
THOMAS GODDARD
were indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of March , 11 yards of stuff, value 20s.; 3 yards of cotton, value 2s.; 2 pairs of socks, value 6d.; 1 pair of shoes, value 1s.; 1 band, value 1s., and 2 frocks, value 2s. , the goods of
Mary Ann Watson
.

MARY ANN WATSON. I am a widow , and live in Praed-street, Paddington
, and keep a haberdasher's-shop . On the 17th of March, at ten o'clock in the morning, I saw these goods safe in my shop - I went out; I went about seven in the evening to Edgware-road, and, between eight and nine, I received information that the shop had been robbed - I went there, and missed these articles; some of them were found in the street - I was fetched next morning to the Police-station, and saw some things like mine - I thought they might be mine, but I was out at the time the shop was robbed; these things are really so very common I cannot identify any of them - the stuff is very common.

WILLIAM HANCOCK
. I am a Policeman. On the 17th of March, about ten minutes past seven o'clock, I saw the three prisoners at the prosecutrix's window - I was in plain clothes, as a patrol; I saw Arthur at the window, the other two were close by him - I could not see whether he took any thing; Goddard stood in front, and Hill stood behind him - they went away from the window; Arthur went on the other side of the way - I collared him, then went into some empty houses, and brought the others out - I found this band in Arthur's hat - Mrs. Watson swore to that.

JOHN EVANS
. I am a Policeman. About ten minutes past seven o'clock I saw Arthur on the opposite side to Watson's house, looking towards some empty houses; I secured him.
MRS. WATSON. These things are so very common I cannot swear to them; I lost things like them.
NOT GUILTY .

916.
JOHN HUGHES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of February , 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Joseph William Hornby
, from his person .

JOSEPH WILLIAM HORNBY. I live in Great Cambridge-street, Hackney-road. On the 19th of February, about seven o'clock in the evening, I was in Old-street
, going into the City - I wanted to use my handkerchief, and on feeling in my pocket it was gone; while I was feeling for it an officer came up, and asked if I had lost any thing - he went about fifteen yards forward, and caught the prisoner, brought him back, and said, "This is the boy who picked your pocket, I saw him;" somebody in the crowd told him not to be afraid - he said, "I have done nothing, what have I to be afraid of?" my handkerchief has not been found.

GEORGE KEMP
. I am a Policeman. On the 19th of February, I saw Mr. Hornby near the London Apprentice- I saw the prisoner in company with another boy, lay hold of Mr. Hornby's coat pocket; I was in plain clothes - he turned round, saw me, and I suppose knew me, for he let go of it; I crossed over to the other side, saw him following Mr. Hornby, watched him, and near the City-road, I saw the prisoner put his hand into the pocket, take the handkerchief out, and give it to the other, who ran away with it directly - I informed Mr. Hornby, and fetched the prisoner back, without losing sight of him; I had seen him before - I think I should know the other lad.

GUILTY . Aged 14. -
Respited .

917.
THOMAS GRIFFITHS
,
JOHN STANFORD
,
JAMES GANDER
, and
THOMAS KELLY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of February , 1 cap, value 9s., the goods of
Hugh McMahon
, the elder, from the person of
Hugh McMahon
, the younger.

ELIZABETH McMAHON
. I am the wife of
Hugh McMahon
, a journeyman tailor - we live in Camden-street, Camden-town
; my son Hugh is eight years old. On the 24th of February, between seven and eight o'clock in theevening, I saw him standing at the door, with the cap on his head - I did not see him go from the door myself; it was a cloth cap, worth 8s. or 9s. - I met him crying in the street in about ten minutes; he complained that some boys who passed the door had dropped a halfpenny, and asked if he would have it - that when he stopped to pick it up, they snatched his cap off, and ran away with it; I have since seen the peak of it, and am certain it is the peak of his cap - I saw the prisoners in custody in about ten minutes, and heard them accusing each other of having taken the cap off the child's head.
Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q.And, of course, they each denied it? A. Yes, I rather think so - I know nothing of a hat being found.

HUGH McMAHON. I live with my parents. I was standing at the door, and saw some boys - I recollect five boys; I cannot recollect whether the prisoners were part of them - the boys took the cap off my head, and ran away with it.
Cross-examined. Q. Did the boy who took the cap put another on your head? A. Yes, but he took that off again.

JOHN BURK
. I live in King's-road, near to Mrs. McMahon. On the 24th of February I saw the last witness in Camden-street, Camden-town, standing outside the door on the flag-stone - I saw the four prisoners, and another boy named Batcheler, hustle him, pushing him about; I cannot swear whether he had any thing on his head, as it was rather dusk - I did not see them do any thing but run away, after hustling him; I saw him again in about ten minutes, and assisted in apprehending Kelly and Stanford.

Cross-examined. Q. What took you to the spot? A. I was going on an errand - I live with my father, and sell fruit about the street; I was not acquainted with Batcheler - I know all the prisoners perfectly well; I did not see the cap taken.

WILLIAM PRICE
. I am a Policeman. On the 24th of February, at near eight o'clock at night, I heard the call of Police, and took Batcheler and Stanford - Burk secured two more; the whole five were together - I charged them with stealing the cap, having seen Mrs. McMahon; I saw one of them throw what appeared to me to be a cap into the road, but I could not secure it - I took Batcheler, Stanford, and Kelly to the station-house; I afterwards went and took he other two from Batcheler's information, as he said, as we went along, "If you won't hurt me I will tell you who stole the cap, and where it is;" I took the others to the station, and went back with him - he showed me where they had thrown the cap, and I found on Griffiths a knife, which the cap had been cut with; the cap had been cut, for the peak, which has been found, has part of the leather fastened to it - I only found the peak where Batcheler took me; it was thrown down an area.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you take on yourself to say that Griffiths cut the cap? A. No, but he is the only one who had the knife - when I took Batcheler he had Kelly's old cap on; I found his own cap next morning in a field- Batcheler did not say he had taken the cap himself.
MRS. McMAHON. I swear this is the peak of my boy's cap; it is leather - I know it, because I beat him severely for breaking it at school; this is broken in two places, the same as his was.

Cross-examined. Q. That accident might happen to any other cap? A. I know this is the peak - my husband made it himself, and there are a great many more holes in it than necessary, as he did not understand the mode of putting it on.

WILLIAM BATCHELER. I am nearly fourteen years old. I was in company with the prisoners on the 24th of February, and saw Mrs. McMahon's son outside the door Griffiths said to him, "I have lost a halfpenny down here, and if you like to find it you may keep it for yourself;" he stooped to look for it, and Griffiths snatched off his cap and put his own on the boy's head - he then took his own off his head again, and ran away; the boy's cap looked like a new one - the other three prisoners were with him at the time; he gave his cap to Kelly, who said, "I am d - d if I don't wear this cap;" I said, "Kelly, mine is a poor old cap, you may as well give me yours;" I saw all this done.

Q. What did you say? A. They were going up higher to steal a till - they had a leg of mutton, and a batter pudding the night before; I told him to give the cap back to the boy, but he would not - I was taken in a quarter of an hour, and told of this directly.

Q. Why not go and tell Mrs. McMahon? A. They all ran away, and I with them - Griffiths cut the peak off the cap with an iron handled knife, he chucked it down an area, and then put it on Kelly's head; I have known the prisoners about three months, but did not keep company with them - I live with my parents; my father sells watercresses, and I go about with him.

Cross-examined. Q. You went about every day with water-cresses? A. Except being in the House of Correction for a month with Stanford, when they took him, and me for being with him - he has been there sixteen times; I was never there but once - I did not keep up an acquaintance with him: I was going out to call my brother to tea this day, and I met him - we had not been out of prison two hours then - they made me go with them, for Griffiths snatched off my cap to make me come, and said he was going to get a batter pudding; it was not my cap that was put on the boy's head - I meant to tell the first officer I met of it; I was always brought up honest - Griffiths only threw the peak into the area; he threw the cap into an old iron-shop - I took the officer to the shop in half an hour, but he could not find it; I got my cap back in the morning.
Stanford's Defence. I deny all Batcheler has said - he did not go to find the cap till the morning.

Kelly's Defence. He said he would go and nick the cap, and we ran on; when he went home he asked Griffiths to lend him his knife, and he cut the peak off - he knocked my cap off, then picked it up, and said my cap was on his head.
Gander's Defence. Batcheler said, "Here is a half-penny for you," and when the boy stopped, he knocked off his hat, and ran away.
Griffiths, Gander, and Kelly received a good character.

STANFORD -
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Transported for Seven Years .
GRIFFITHS - GUILTY. Aged 13.
GANDER - GUILTY. Aged 9.
KELLY - GUILTY. Aged 14.

Judgment Respited
.
Second London Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

918.
WILLIAM HUGHES
was indicted for
a misdemeanor .
NOT GUILTY .

919.
WILLIAM GEORGE SHARP
was indicted for
a misdemeanor .

HENRY STOKES
. I am a meat-salesman at Newgate-market. On the 7th of February the prisoner came to me, and said he wanted a leg of mutton, or pork, for Mr. Knock, of Well-street, who is a customer of mine; we let him have a leg of mutton, believing he came from Mr. Knock, whose apprentice I knew he had been.

JOHN KNOCK
. I am a bookbinder, and deal with Mr. Stokes. The prisoner was my apprentice for twelve months, and I used to send him for meat; he was not in my employ on the 7th of February - I did not send him for this meat; he never brought it to me - he had absconded from me a month.
MARIA KNOCK. I am Mr. Knock's wife. I did not authorize the prisoner to go to Mr. Stokes' for meat - he never brought it.
Prisoner's Defence. I never went there after I left Mr. Knock.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Whipped and Discharged.

920.
THOMAS SMITH
and
ANN SMITH
were indicted for
a misdemeanor .

MARIA HOWARD
. I am a servant, and live in Leonard-street. On the 29th of March, about five o'clock, I overtook the prisoners in Newgate-street - they were quite strangers to me; I only saw the male prisoner at first; they were not walking together - he was stooping when I overtook him, and said he had picked something up; he went on, stopped, and I overtook him again three or four yards further; then he showed me some earrings; he went on to the corner of Newgate-street - he had not walked above a dozen yards altogether when he showed a parcel to me; he said he had picked them up, and was never so lucky in his life before as to pick any thing up of any value - I said, "Have you?" he then crossed over to the New Post-office, and near the Bull and Mouth, St. Martin's-le-grand, I saw him again on the same side of the way as I was on; he showed me an ear-ring and ring - I had seen the ring before; he asked me to read the bill for him; they were tied in paper; I read it - the amount was 5l. 18s. 6d., it was for a pair of ear rings and two gold rings - we gave it to the Magistrate at Guildhall, and it has not been returned- he asked if I would buy them, and said I should have them for 1l.; that he was in distress, and a little money would be more useful to him than the parcel - (I did not see the female prisoner till the man was taken into custody;) I said I could not, and then he said I should have them for 15s.; I gave him 14s. 6d. for them - he then left me, and I did not see him any more till he was taken into custody - I took the ear-rings and rings; the officer, who had been watching, came up, and asked if I had bought any thing; I delivered them to him - he took both the prisoners into custody.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Did you not at first deny to the officer that you had bought any thing? A. Yes; I then walked on five or six yards; the officer spoke to me again - I told him, and delivered them to him; I did not suppose I had done wrong; the prisoner stopped and spoke to me first.

ROBERT TYRRELL. I am an officer of the Post-office. On the 29th of March, about five o'clock in the afternoon, I saw the two prisoners in company, going backward and forward in Newgate-street, which excited my suspicion I saw the man follow the prosecutrix down Newgate-street, and show her something in a paper; he followed her to the end of Jewin-street, and suddenly parted from her - the female who was in his company kept on the opposite side; I told the street-keeper to call the prosecutrix back, and just at that moment the male prisoner crossed over, gave something to the female, and said,"Here is 14s. 6d.;" I took hold of them, pushed them into a house, and took the 14s. 6d. out of the female's hand - I am certain they were in company; she was very reluctant to give up the 14s. 6d., and dropped a ring out of her hand; it appeared a wedding-ring - I searched the male prisoner, and found in his waistcoat pocket a strip of paper, on which was written "Two pairs of gold ear-rings, two gold keys," amounting to 5l. 18s. 6d.; I gave that paper to the Magistrate, and it was lost - the street-keeper came back to me, and said the prosecutrix had bought nothing; I sent him back again; he brought her back, and said she had bought the ear-rings - I found a key in the male prisoner's pocket; I searched his lodgings in Green-street, Commercial-road, and on his shelf found another paper, with the same words on it.

Cross-examined. Q. You say they were together - had you your eyes on them the whole time? A. I cannot say that I had; I saw them for four or five minutes before he addressed the prosecutrix, and saw him speak to several young women, which excited my suspicion - he was standing when the prosecutrix passed him; he then went in front of her.

MARIA ANN COPELAND. I am matron of Giltspur-street Compter. When the female prisoner was brought in the officer requested me to search her - I took her into an adjoining room, and saw her put her hand to her bonnet I felt her bonnet, and said, "What have you here?" she said, "Nothing but curl-papers;" I said, "I insist on searching, for there is something more;" she was going to strike me - I turned to call the officer, and when I returned with him, she approached towards me, and said, "You may now search me," and I picked a paper off the ground, containing four rings.

JOSEPH HAWK RIGGE. I am a street-keeper. Tyrrell beckoned to me about the middle of Aldersgate-street - I followed the prosecutrix, and asked her to return with me, and if she had bought any thing - she said No, at first; she afterwards gave me the ear-rings and a mourning-ring- I have also those picked up in the prison, and have had them ever since.

HENRY LESTER
. I am a jeweller. These ear-rings are brass, and not worth 1d. - the rings are brass, and worth nothing; I would not give 1 1/2d. for them all.
MR. BARRY (on behalf of the defendants) addressed the Court.

T. SMITH -
GUILTY . Aged 40.
Transported for Seven Years .

A. SMITH -
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

921.
JOHN EVANS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of February , 1 pair of shoes, value 5s. , the goods of
Galen Bamfield
.

CHRISTOPHER BAMFIELD
. I am the son of
Galen Bamfield
- he is a boot and shoe-maker , and lives in the Strand
. On the 23rd of February, about five o'clock in the afternoon, the prisoner came in, and asked for a pair of boots I went outside the window to get him a boot; I saw him take these shoes, and put them into his pocket - I came in, and he said the boots I showed him were too light, he wanted strong ones; he went out, and I called Stop thief! he was taken without my losing sight of him, and the shoes found in his coat pocket.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that the shoes found on him, he had just taken out of pledge.
C. BAMFIELD. It is not true - I saw him take them off the shop-board.

GUILTY . Aged 26. -
Confined Three Months .

922.
JOSEPH DANIELS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of March , 1 apron, value 1s. 3d. , the goods of
Peter Puttock
.

GEORGE BRODIE
. I live in Chapel-street
, just opposite Mr. Puttock's. On the 22nd of March, about five o'clock, I saw the prisoner looking in at the window - I saw him snatch an apron off the eggs in the shop, and run away; I saw him running, but could not catch him - I had seen him several times before, and knew him perfectly well; I saw him in custody the next day.

CHARLES CLARK
. I apprehended the prisoner in a yard, among a parcel of boys - I knew him well by the description given of him; when he saw me he ran into a house, and tried to hide himself - I took him, and he said,"What do you want?" I said, "You will soon know," and as we went along he said, "I know nothing about the apron;" I had not mentioned an apron.
PETER PUTTOCK. I was at home, and missed the apron, but did not see it taken.

GUILTY . Aged 13. -
Transported for Seven Years .

923.
SARAH DRISCOLL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of March , 3 drinking-glasses, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
John Gurney
.

JOHN GURNEY. I keep the Rum Puncheon, in White-cross-street
. On the 31st of March, about six o'clock in the evening, the prisoner came in, and had half a pint of porter in a glass - she stopped about an hour and a half, then went out, and we missed three glasses; I followed her to the Asylum for the Houseless, in Playhouse-yard, and found three glasses on her, which are mine - one has my name on it.

GUILTY . Aged 34. -
Transported for Seven Years .

924.
ELIZABETH CRESWICK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of March , 1 coat, value 10s.; 1 pair of breeches, value 2s.; 3 shirts, value 6s.; 1 pair of stockings, value 1s. 6d.; 2 waistcoats, value 2s., and 1 umbrella, value 1s. , the goods of
James Goodhall
.

JAMES GOODHALL. I live in Wilson-street, Somers'-town
. On the 22nd of March the prisoner was cleaning out a room at my house, and at night, when she was gone, I missed a sheet off the bed, a coat out of a box, and the breeches off the table; she was my char-woman - I have known her two years: I never allowed her to pawn my property.

JAMES LIMBIRD
. I apprehended the prisoner - she gave me the duplicates of the property.

GEORGE WADE
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Charlton-street, Somers'-town. I have all the articles stated in the indictment, which were pawned by the prisoner, at different times.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner pleaded distress.

GUILTY . Aged 42. -
Confined Three Months .

925.
CHARLES BRINKLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of March , 1 jewel-case, value 40s., and 1 flute, value 10s. , the goods of
Samuel Starkey
.

SAMUEL STARKEY. I live in Queen-square, Aldersgate-street
. On the 24th of March, between three and four o'clock, a person whom I employ out of doors, sent his son with some work; he rang the bell - the boy answered it; he said he would wait five minutes for an answer - during that time somebody entered the parlour, and took this case and flute; my boy went down, found the parlour door open, and gave an alarm - I went out, and caught the prisoner within five minutes, in Peter's-lane, St. John-street, with the jewel-case under his arm, covered with a handkerchief; I found my flute in his trousers pocket - he was quite a stranger.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

JOHN ABRAHALL
. I am the prosecutor's errand boy - the bell rang; I came down to a boy, and left the door open, but I did not see the prisoner - I knew the flute was in the parlour.
Prisoner's Defence. I was coming across Smithfield - a gentleman came up, and asked me to carry these things to the Angel, at Islington - I thought he was behind me at the time.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Transported for Seven Years .

926.
GEORGE AUSTIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of March , 6 silver spoons, value 20s. , the goods of
William Michie
.

WILLIAM MICHIE. I keep the Spread Eagle, in Oxford-street
. The prisoner is quite a stranger to me. On the 21st of March, between ten and eleven o'clock, I missed these spoons off the sideboard in the coffee-room - there were eleven on the sideboard, but only six were taken; they were in the waiter's charge - I had not seen the prisoner in the house.

HYLA BETTS
. I am a refiner of gold and silver, and live in Long-acre. On the 23rd of March the prisoner offered these spoons for sale, cut into pieces; I suspected he had not come honestly by them, and detained him; he said they were given him by a friend to dispose of - I sent for a Policeman, and gave him in charge.

THOMAS HEYGATE
. I am a Policeman. I received the prisoner in charge, with the property.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I was coming over the water, and met a friend in the Blackfriars-road; I went home with her, and after waiting some time, (I was tipsy) I received them from her - she put into my hand a paper; I did not knowwhat it was till morning; when I found what I had got, I thought they were of no use, and she intended them for sale; I know nothing of the robbery.

GUILTY . Aged 29. -
Transported for Seven Years .

927.
ROBERT WESTWICK, alias MITCHELL
, was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of March , 2 shoes, value 2s. , the goods of
William Hayhan
.

JOHN JENKINS
. I am in the employ of
William Hayhan
; he is a shoemaker , and lives in Ratcliff-highway
. On the 2nd of March, a person said a man had taken some shoes - I went out, and found the prisoner about twenty doors off I said, "You have stolen my master's shoes" - he said he had not - I told him he had - he then pulled them from under his jacket; they were master's, and had been hanging at our door.

Prisoner's Defence I was passing the shop - I picked up the shoes a yard and a half from the prosecutor's door; I carried them publicly in my hand to see who would own them, till I got near Old Gravel-lane; I then put them under my jacket - this man asked me for them, and I gave them to him.

GUILTY . Aged 60. -
Confined Three Weeks .

928.
THOMAS POSTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of March , 4 pieces of carpet, value 3s., and 40 pieces of candle, value 6d. , the goods of
James Willis
.

JAMES WILLIS
. I keep Fladong's-hotel, Oxford-street
. The prisoner was in my service twenty-two months, as porter , and was so on the 1st of March; many gentlemen complained of losing property - I got a search-warrant, and found on his premises a quantity of carpet, pieces of candle, and a number of duplicates of glass, which I believe to be my property; I have pieces of carpet similar to those found, and the candles are a peculiar make - I have missed candles from time to time.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What is the peculiar make? A. They are made to fit candlesticks which I have - they are not a common length; I had them made short for the use of the bed-room; they are tallow - I had not sold any carpets - I had a man named Hill in my employ; I sold him some carpet once, but I sold none while the prisoner lived with me - when I said I had not sold any carpets, I meant while the prisoner had lived with me - some of these pieces are old, and some are much worn - I know nothing of the prisoner buying any carpet of Hill - I may have sold him six or seven patterns, or there might be twenty; these may be called remnants; they are cut up I took the prisoner on the recommendation of our head porter, Hill - I believe he had lived formerly with my predecessor, for four or five years.

EDWARD RURRIDGE
. I am an officer, of High-street. I went to the prisoner's lodgings on the 14th of March; he was not at home, but his wife was - I found some of these carpets on the floor, and some on a chair - the candles were in a cupboard - I was called down stairs, and when I got up again, I found his wife had removed them into another room - I took the prisoner there between five and six o'clock next morning, and told him it was on suspicion of stealing various things from his master - he said, "My wife has told me all about it; I have not taken any thing" - he did not show the least fear.
NOT GUILTY .

929.
JANE TAYLOR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of March , 2 pewter pots, value 2s. , the goods of
George White
.

JAMES PAKES
. I am servant to George White, who keeps the Hope and Anchor, in Hereford-street
. On the 8th of March, about eight o'clock in the evening, I was telling my brother what a quantity of pots had been stolen, and I observed the prisoner in the tap-room - I was standing at the door; she came out and stood by my side, and then shifted to the lower step - I heard something rattle, saw her stooping, and I went to her, and picked up a pot; where it came from I cannot tell - I took her to my master, and on looking down, saw another pot hanging below her clothes - he sent for an officer.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you take the pot from under her clothes? A. No; it hung below her clothes; I cannot say what it hung to; she was tipsy- she said it was tied to her gown - there were a set of fellows larking in the room - she complained it had been tied to her tail - I do not believe she meant to steal them.
NOT GUILTY .
NEW COURT. TUESDAY, APRIL 12.
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

930.
JOSEPH PRAGNELL
was indicted for
embezzlement ; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Confined Two Months .

931.
CHARLES ALLINGTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of February , 2 fixtures, (i. e.) 2 coppers, belonging to
Samuel Ridge
, and fixed to a building ; against the Statute, & c.

SAMUEL RIDGE. I live at Bishop Bonner's-hall, in the parish of Bethnal-green
. On the 25th of February I missed two coppers from a house of mine in the neighbourhood, which I had let.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. I believe you had the misfortune to have a tenant named Kendall? A. I had - he ran away; I had my rent, because the goods were sold - the key was delivered up to me the day this bill was found; I do not know where Kendall is.

WILLIAM CASTELL
. I was in a barn at Bonner's-hall on a Friday morning - I heard something; I went out, and saw the prisoner with two coppers on his back - he threw them down when he saw me, and ran off; I have seen them fitted to two places in the kitchen at Bonner's-hall, and they fit exactly; he was twenty or thirty yards from the house when I saw him - there are gates in front of the house, and they were open.
Cross-examined. Q.Do you know Kendall? A. I know he lived there - he is gone off; the door was open, but had not been broken.

DONALD McDONALD
. I am a Police-constable. I was on Twig Folly-bridge, about four hundred yards from the prosecutor's - I heard a cry of Stop thief! and took the prisoner, who was running; I took him to Bonner's-hall, where the coppers were afterwards fitted.

Cross-examined. Q.Did he not tell you he was engaged to carry the coppers? A. Yes, that some person had the coppers on the ground, and said they would givehim 6d. to carry them across the field - nothing in the least suspicious was found on him.

WILLIAM BROOKS
. I was in the yard at Mr. Ridge's- I heard the cry of Stop thief! I went about twenty yards in front of Mr. Ridge's, and saw two coppers laying in a ditch, about sixty or seventy yards from the place they were fitted to; I took them, and went and fitted them in the places - they fitted exactly.

Prisoner's Defence. A gentleman asked me to carry them across the field, and he was to give me 6d. for it - he ran away; I was frightened, and threw them down - the gentleman then called Stop thief! and I ran away; there was a man with the person who hired me, who called out Mr. Kendall - he was a tall man, with a blue coat and light breeches.
MR. RIDGE re-examined. Q. How long had Kendall been away? A. Since about Christmas - I have not seen him since; he had the key in his possession.

Q. How lately before these coppers were missed had there been a sale? A.Shortly after Christmas - I do not know whether the house had been empty; the brokers might have gone into it - it was not in my possession; Kendall was a gentlemanly man - he had the use of the fixtures, which had been left by a former tenant.

WILLIAM CASTELL
. I saw two men with a truck, in a lane twenty or thirty yards from the prisoner - it was a truck that would have carried the coppers; there was a field - the prisoner was going towards the truck; it was going on - I did not notice the men, nor see what was in the truck.
NOT GUILTY .

932.
JOHN BECKENHAM
and
JAMES WEBB
were indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of March , 1 bushel of oats, value 4s., and 1 sack, value 2s. , the goods of
Thomas Meredith
.

WILLIAM GREGORY
. I am a Police-constable. On the night of the 16th of March I was on duty in Praed-street, Paddington - I saw Beckenham coming down with a sack of corn, and he asked me if I could tell him which was No. 137; I said I thought he knew as well as I did, it was not at that end of the street; I then asked what he had in the sack - he said a bushel of corn which he was going to take from Mr. Meredith's wharf to Mr. Whitmore's, and if I went with him there I should find it was all right; I went with him, and Mr. Whitmore denied all knowledge of it - I then took him to the station, and in going down the street he said, "The whole of it is, it is stolen corn, and I had it from
James Webb
from Mr. Meredith's stable;" I went and informed Mr. Meredith, and he gave charge of Beckenham - I went and took Webb at Mr. Meredith's stable, No. 9 wharf, Paddington; he said, "I own I gave the corn to Beckenham to take to Mr. Whitmore's, and I hope my master will look over it;" he said he was to bring back 4s.

Beckenham. I said I was going to Whitmore's, but I am no scholar, and do not know the number; Whitmore said he had not ordered it, and I said I would go back and ask the master if he had ordered Webb to send it any where - if it was not ordered it must be stolen. Witness. No, he did not say that - the number he asked for is where he lives himself.

THOMAS MEREDITH. I have a stable at No. 9 wharf Paddington - Webb is my carman ; I have seen these oats and sack - they are mine; my name is on the sack I have some of the same oats in my bulk; Beckenham was employed occasionally, and had been that day unloading coals - I believe I have been robbed to a great extent, and my horses have suffered; Webb has received money from time to time, and paid it over to me - I sell corn in small quantities.
Beckenham's Defence. I was completely out of work; I did not know these were stolen.

BECKENHAM -
GUILTY . Aged 30.

WEBB -
GUILTY . Aged 31.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor.
Confined Three Months .

933.
WILLIAM ANDERSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of March , 2 rings, value 16s., and 1 pair of ear-rings, value 15s. , the goods of
Elizabeth Rider
.

ELIZABETH RIDER. I am a widow , and live in Elbow-lane, Shadwell
. On the 5th of March the prisoner came to lodge with me, and remained till the Wednesday following - as I was opening one of my boxes he saw some duplicates; in consequence of information I examined the duplicates again on the 19th of March - I missed eight of them; one was for a jacket, another for a pair of trousers, another for a shawl, another for some ear-rings, and some for other things.

WILLIAM HUDSON
. I am an apprentice to Mr. Harrison, a watch-maker, in Upper East Smithfield. I purchased some duplicates of a person named Williams, who is gone to sea - I took the articles out of pawn.
NOT GUILTY .

934. JOHN BRADFORD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of April , 2 crowns, 1 half-crown, and 1 sixpence, the monies of
John Franks
, alias
John Francis
, from his person .

JOHN FRANKS
. I am a seaman , and lodge at the Dundee Arms, Wapping. On Saturday, the 3rd of April, I was at a public-house, and met a young woman, named Jane - I went with her to a house, where I saw the prisoner and two women; I then had 14s. 6d. in my pocket- the young woman was drunk; she invited me to go to the house - the prisoner asked me to play at cards with him, which I did; it was my deal - I took the cards in my hand, gave him six, and took six for myself; he let one of the cards fall on the table, and said it was a misdeal - we were playing at all-fours; the prisoner then said, "You d - d black b - r, you have got no money;" I put my hand into my left-hand waistcoat pocket, took out my money, and laid it on the table - he then gave me a sudden blow in the eye, and when I put my hand to my eye, he took up my money, put his hand into my pocket and tore it, but I had no money there; I went out of the house, and, as I did not know the number, I took out my knife, and cut four marks on the window-shutter- I got an officer, and the prisoner was taken sitting on a chair; I was sober.

THOMAS BATES
. I am a Police-constable. At twenty minutes before two o'clock on the Sunday morning, the prisoner came to me - I went with him to No. 9, Matchwalk, Shadwell - I saw four cuts on the shutter - I went in,and saw the prisoner and three women - I was going to search the prisoner with Serjeant Garde, who was with me, when he pulled 15s. out of his pocket; he said it was his own - he put 14s. into the serjeant's hand, and 1s. fell on the table - he said he had changed a sovereign at the Green Dragon, Stepney, and then afterwards said at the Blue Anchor.

WILLIAM ROBERT GARDE
. I am a Police-serjeant. I went to the house and saw the marks on the shutters - what has been said is correct.

Prisoner's Defence. I called to see a friend - the prosecutor was called in by one of the ladies; he drank out of a pot of porter, and they asked him to play at all fours; we played, he made a mis-deal, and I told him of it - he got up, put his hands across, and said, "I will not pay"- he pulled out no money, and I never saw a farthing of money while I was there - he went backwards, and was there half an hour with one of the women; we then played at cards, and when he got up and put his arm across, I just touched him a cross back-hander, and said, "I won't play any more, I don't think you have any money" - he is one of the biggest brutes that ever lived, to swear that I ever got off my seat - the woman he went home with says he had but 1s. 8 1/2d. in his pocket.

JANE HILLYER
. I live at No. 9, Well's-row, Shadwell. On that Saturday night I went into the Ship and Shears -I saw the prosecutor there drinking a pint of beer; I went with him to the house where the prisoner was - I was not sober, and I was not very tipsy - I took the prosecutor into my room; he wanted to stay all night with me - I asked what he was going to give me; he looked into all his pockets and said all he had was 1s. 0 1/2d. - I said I could not stay with him for that - he then went out of my room, and did not give me any money.

EMMA BERRY
. On that Saturday night the prosecutor came into my room, and said he was not going to stay with that young woman, as he had not money enough - he asked if I would stay with him, and he would pay me the next day - I said No - he then said he would have a game at cards for half-a-pint of gin; while we were playing, he began to cheat me, and then I would not play with him; he then said he would keep playing with the prisoner; he dropped a card, and said it was the prisoner who dropped it; some words arose between them; he called the prisoner some names - the prisoner got up and struck him, across the table, on the eye - there was nothing done to the prosecutor's pocket after he was struck, nor before, but what he did himself when he took out the 1s. 0 1/2d. and put them in again - when he was struck he got up, bade us good night, and went out - he came in again, stood before the prisoner, and said, "You have struck me on one side, now strike me on the other - the prisoner would not, and said he wanted to have nothing to say to him - he then went out, and returned with the officer.

ELIZABETH FOGWELL
. The prisoner has lodged with me for nine months. On that Saturday he had been at work with my husband, and received a sovereign and a halfpenny, the same as my husband did, but I was not there; I saw him have the sovereign in his possession at six o'clock, and at seven he changed it at the Green Dragon, Stepney; he did not come home to my house that night - we were waiting for him; he is a coal-whipper.

ANN CHAMBERLAIN
. The prisoner was at my house at seven o'clock that night with the silver in his hand; there appeared to be nearly 1l. worth, and there was a five shilling piece among it.

ANN IVES
. I live at No. 2, James-street, Limehousefields. I am a tailoress; on that Saturday evening I saw the prisoner with some silver in his hand, which he took out to look for 1s. to send for some peppermint; I saw some half-crowns amongst it.

THOMAS BATES
re-examined. Q. Before you took the prisoner, did the prosecutor state what money he had lost? A. Yes; he said he had lost 13s. 6d. or 14s. - I have inquired, and found the prisoner has got his living by coal-work till the last five months.

JURY. Q. Did the prosecutor state what his silver consisted of? A. Yes; he said a crown-piece, and some half-crowns - I found on the prisoner one crown, three half-crowns, two shillings, and one sixpence.
Prisoner. There was 1s. and 1 1/2d found on him, and that was all the money he had.
GUILTY of stealing only . Aged 38.
Transported for Seven Years .

935.
WILLIAM BENJAMIN BRAY
and
CHARLES JOHN WALMSLEY
were indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 9th of February , 9 sticks of timber, value 40l., the goods of
John Chatfield
and others, well knowing them to have been stolen ; to which they both pleaded.

GUILTY . -
Confined Six Months .

936.
RICHARD THURBORNE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of February , 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
Herbert Turner
, from his person ; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

HERBERT TURNER. I am a surgeon , and live in Dean-street, St. Thomas', Southwark. On the night of the 23rd of February, about half-past seven o'clock, I was in John-street
, going home with a friend - I felt something at my coat pocket, but I did not turn immediately; I waited to have my pocket picked - I then turned, and saw the prisoner with my handkerchief in his hand, and another boy near him, who ran away - I caught the prisoner directly; I seized his hand and the handkerchief at the same moment- he said he was not the boy who picked the pocket, and wished me to let him go; he said the handkerchief was on the ground, and he picked it up - the officer came in a few minutes, and I gave the boy and the handkerchief to him.

JAMES BOYCE COX
. I am the Police-constable. I received the prisoner on the 23rd of February; this is the handkerchief - it was partly in his hand, and partly in the prosecutor's.

Prisoner. The prosecutor had me in his possession a quarter of an hour before the officer came up; he had put the handkerchief into his pocket, and took it out again - he said he would do all he could to send me out of the country.

MR. TURNER. When I turned round the other boy ran away, and the other was about arm's length from me - I turned the instant I thought the handkerchief clear from my person - the prisoner was not running; he said he was innocent, and wished me to go to his mother's.

Prisoner's Defence (written). I beg to assert that I am innocent of the crime imputed to me; I was passing at the moment on an errand for my mother - I saw the handkerchief laying on the ground; I picked it up (thinking it had been dropped by some person), when I was seized and charged with stealing the handkerchief.

JOHN DOVE
. I am a Police-constable. I know the prisoner; I saw him tried here on the 6th of January last- I am sure he is the same person; I have the certificate of his conviction - (read).

GUILTY . - Aged 15. -
Transported for Life .

937.
GEORGE BLAKE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of March , 1 chaise-rug, value 2s., the goods of
John Cotton
; and 1 pair of boots, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
William Everett
.

THOMAS JOSEPH WEST
. I am a Police-constable. On the Tuesday before the 5th of March, I was in Hopkin-street, St. James; I saw the prisoner carry something under his arm, into an old iron-shop - I followed him, and saw he had this pair of boots and this chaise rug; he asked if they bought such things - the girl saw me behind him, and said they did not; I asked what he had got - he said an old rug which his master had given him to cut for horse-cloths - I went to inquire at a place he sent me to, and it was denied - I said to him the next morning, "It was useless for you to give me so much trouble last night;" he said, "I will not give you any more trouble; I took the rug from Howard's livery-stable, in Jermyn-street;" the boots, he said, were his own, and he was in distress - his wife and children appeared to be so.

WILLIAM EVERETT
. I am coachman to Lord Romney, of York-street, St. James'. These boots are mine - I kept them in Howard's stable, in Jermyn-street; the prisoner had been at work for a few days there - I missed them the day after they were lost.

EDWARD ROBERTS. I am groom to John Cotton, Esq. , of No.12, Carlton-chambers, Regent-street. This rug belongs to him; I did not miss it till the officer brought it me - I had seen the prisoner working two or three days at Howard's livery stables.
The prisoner pleaded distress.

GUILTY . Aged 33. -
Confined Two Days .

938.
JOHN BOSTON
and
JAMES CLARK
were indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of February , 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d., the goods of a person unknown, from his person .

THOMAS JOSEPH WEST
. I am a Police-constable. On the night of the 24th of February I was in company with Hobbs, in St. James-street
, about nine o'clock - the two prisoners were pointed out to me by a person, named Dorrell - I saw a gentleman and lady there - Boston went behind the gentleman, and drew a handkerchief out of his left-hand pocket, took it in his left-hand, and put it behind him to the other prisoner - I put my arms round them, and called to Hobbs, "They have got it;" Hobbs came and took one - I took the other, and the handkerchief laid on the ground at their feet - it was an illumination night, and owing to the gangs that were about, it was impossible to get the gentleman without losing the prisoners.

THOMAS HOBBS
. I am a Police-constable. I was with West - I saw the prisoners going up against gentlemen's pockets; we watched them some time - West called to me; I went up, put their feet on one side, and took up the handkerchief between the two prisoners.

GEORGE DORHELL
. I saw the prisoners together on the night of the 24th of February - they attempted several pockets, and I mentioned it to the officers; I saw Boston take hold of a gentleman's pocket, put his hand into his pocket, and take out this handkerchief.
THOMAS HOBBS. This is the handkerchief. I asked Boston what was on it - he said he did not believe there was any thing on it, but there is J. C. on it.

Clark's Defence. There was a mob of two thousand people - the handkerchief was picked up behind two women; I was two yards from this young man - I had not been in the crowd two minutes before I was taken.
Boston's Defence. The officer caught hold of me first, I asked what he wanted, and he let me go - the J. C. are the initials of my second father's name.

JAMES COSGROVE
. I am step-father to Boston. I have known him since he was three months old - he never knew his own name till lately, as he was always reared with me and served his time to me - he always went by my name till he was taken, and then he gave his right name.
JURY. Q. Had you any silk handkerchiefs? A. Yes, of different colours, but it is seldom I wear one - my son has taken them when he thought proper; I do not know whether I lost one or not.

BOSTON -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

CLARK -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Life .

939.
WILLIAM CARR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of April , 1 chaise-harness, value 40s. , the goods of
Samuel Ewins
.

JAMES BOYCE
COX. I am a Police-officer. On the night of the 4th of April I was in St. John-street - I saw the prisoner and another come out of the Pewter Platter-yard
; the prisoner was carrying a set of harness on his shoulder; he crossed into Wilderness-row before I stopped him - I asked what he had there; he said it was his own, that he was going to take it home, and I might go with him and see where he took it to - I said it was of no consequence where he was going to take it to, but I wished to know where he got it; he then went down Pewter Platter-yard (there was another man with him); he threw down the harness under a cart, and said that was where he found it when he went down to a place of convenience - I took him to the station; but before I took him away, I saw a coach-house door open; when I had taken him away, I returned and got a light; I then found the coach-house door was broken open, and this piece of a lock was inside.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. He took you to the yard where he said he found the harness? A. Yes, but I had seen him come out there - this was about half-past twelve o'clock.

JESSE EAST
. I am in the service of Mr. Samuel Ewins, a bookbinder, who lives in Duke-street, Smithfield - he has a coach-house in Pewter Platter-yard. On the afternoon of the 4th of April I fastened the door of the coach-house, leaving this harness inside it - I found the door broken open, and the padlock broken; this is his harness.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you know where the barness was? A.When I went home I left it in the coach-house, at half-past five o'clock.

GUILTY . Aged 30. -
Transported for Seven Years .

940.
ANN CREATON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of March , 8 stockings, value 4s.; 2 gloves, value 1s; 3 wristbands, value 6d.; 1 petticoat, value 2s. and 3 pieces of ribbon, value 3d. , the goods of
George Riddle
.

CHRISTIANA RIDDLE
. I am the wife of George Riddle - he keeps the White Swan, at Shadwell
; the prisoner lived servant with me for eleven months, and left on the 16th of February. I missed a few articles while she was with me, but I was ill in the country in the summer, and when I came home I did not ask any one in the house about them - I missed some silk handkerchiefs and a coral necklace from a box in my bed-room; I had the necklace safe on New Year's Day, and on the Friday before, the 11th of March, I missed it - I went to ask the prisoner about it; she pleaded her innocence.

JAMES MORGAN
. I am a Police-serjeant. In consequence of information I went to the prisoner; she delivered her keys to me, and told me she lodged at No. 1, Twine-court; I went with the prosecutor there; I opened a box with a key the prisoner gave me; some articles there were claimed by the prosecutor - I brought them away; I told the prisoner what I had found; she said at first there was nothing belonging to her master, and then she said they were what her mistress gave her - here are four pairs of stockings, a petticoat, one pair of gloves, some wristbands, and some ribbon.

MRS. RIDDLE. These came from the wash while I was in the country, and I believe she took them only till they were owned - they are my property, and I never gave them to her; there is no mark on them - this petticoat I can swear to: it was sent to wash while I was in the country - I had returned four months when she was apprehended - here is a pair of gloves, but no mark on them; I have never found my necklace.
Prisoner's Defence. My mistress may forget, but she gave me that old petticoat before she went into the country.
MRS. RIDDLE. I do not remember it, but I could not swear I did not - she was not in the country with me.
NOT GUILTY .

941.
WILLIAM DAVISON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of February , 25 yards of cotton, value 25s. the goods of
Edward Hill
; and that he had before been convicted of felony.

HENRY LENNON
. I am a Police-constable. At half-past nine o'clock on the night of the 24th of February I saw the prisoner near Shadwell-market, by a door in an alley; he had his jacket and waistcoat off, and his shirt-sleeves turned up - I asked what he was doing; he said he was a sailor, and was going to sleep down there - I found his jacket and waistcoat were over this piece of cotton; when he took the waistcoat up to put it on I saw the cotton - I found the prosecutor's shop about three hundred yards from the place.

WILLIAM GOULBOURN
. I am in the employ of Mr. Edward Hill - he is a linen-draper , of High-street, Shadwell
. This cotton is his property - it has two marks on it, in my own hand-writing; I had seen it safe about six o'clock in the evening, and it was brought to the shop between nine and ten o'clock.

CHARLES WALTER WHEELER
. I know the prisoner; I saw him here last Session - he was tried, and pleaded starvation; I know he is the man - I got this certificate of his conviction from Mr. Clark's office - (read).

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .

942.
MARY HOWE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of March , 1 coat, value 8s; 2 blankets, value 1s. 6d; 1 sheet, value 3s.; 1 shirt, value 3s.; 1 frock, value 1s., and 1 apron, value 6d. , the goods of
Michael Hanley
.

CATHERINE HANLEY. I am the wife of Michael Hanley - we lodge on the first floor in George-street, Islington
. On the afternoon of the 15th of March, I returned home, and missed the prisoner, who had been employed to take care of my place and my children, in my absence - I also missed some articles.

JAMES COLLINS
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner; she gave me the next morning the duplicate of a coat, pawned for 4s., at Mr. Drew's at Islington; the prisoner told me she had pawned it.

GEORGE STOWELL
. I am in the service of Mr. Drew. This coat was pawned by the prisoner on the 14th of March; I have also a shirt, an apron, and a sheet, pawned by her on different days.

JOSEPH BROOKER
. I am in the service of Mr. Sherwood. I have a remnant of cotton and a child's dress, pawned by the prisoner, on different days.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 58.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutrix.
Confined Three Months .

943.
THOMAS LEADBETTER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of February , 1 pair of breeches, value 7s., and 1 pair of trousers, value 6s , the goods of
Samuel Lowe
.

MARY ANN LOWE
. I am the wife of
Samuel Lowe
- he lives in Brown's-lane, Spitalfields
, and is a tailor . On the Saturday before the 28th of February I was in the shop, and saw the prisoner about for a quarter of an hour; I went into my back parlour, to my little girl, who had fallen down, and on coming into the shop again, I missed these articles - the trousers had been on the doorpost, and the breeches near the door; I had put them there not long before - I went out, and missed the prisoner; I went in again, and sat down some time, when I thought I saw him on the other side of the way, with a bundle under his arm- I looked, and saw the strings and buttons of the smallclothes hanging out of the bundle; I called the Policeman, who ran, and took him - these are the articles; the breeches are worth 7s. 2d. and the trousers 6s. 3d.

WILLIAM BEALE
. I am a Police-serjeant. I was in Brown's-lane, and in consequence of what this lady said, I pursued, and took the prisoner - he was running, with this bundle under his arm.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I was in Spitalfields-market, and a young man told me to go with him for a parcel; hewent and brought this bundle - he told me to hold it while he tied his shoe; I heard a cry of Stop thief! and ran.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Confined Three Months .

944.
THOMAS MASON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of March , 4 shawls, value 4l. , the goods of
Charles Earith
, his master.

CHARLES EARITH. I am a silk-dyer , and live in Goswell-street. The prisoner was in my employ a fortnight; I missed some articles, and in consequence of information, I gave him into custody - I have since seen four shawls, worth a guinea each, at a pawnbroker's - I missed one on the 17th of March, and one on the 19th.

CHARLES WORLEY
. I am foreman to Mr. Cassel, a pawnbroker, in Old-street. I produce a crape shawl, pawned at our house by the prisoner, in the name of
Thomas Mason
, for 4s. - he said he came from his father: he came again with this other shawl 1-1 questioned him again- I was not satisfied with his answers - I told him to go and get his father; he went away.

HENRY JEROME
. I am shopman to Mr. Jones, a pawnbroker, in Wood-street. Spitalfields. I have two crope shawls, pawned by the prisoner on the 17th of March - I advanced him 5s. on each of them, and then 2s. more on one of them - he had been there before, for his parents.

GUILTY. Aged 14. -
Judgment Respited
.

945.
RICHARD MILLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of March , 1 trunk, value 4s.; 1 cloak, value 1s., 3 jackets, value 5s.; 1 coat, value 10s.; 1 pair of trousers, value 3s.; 3 shirts, value 6s; 2 fronts, value 1s. 6d.; 5 waistcoats, value 8s.; 2 pairs of drawers, value 3s.; 4 handkerchiefs, value 10s; 2 pairs of stockings, value 1s., and 2 caps, value 2s. 6d. the goods of
Henry Turner
.

2nd COUNT, stating them to be the goods of
Benjamin Walker
.

3rd COUNT, stating them to be the goods of
Richard Wells
.
4th COUNT, stating them to be the goods of a certain person or persons unknown.

BENJAMIN WALKER
. I keep the Bell and Crown public-house, in Kingsland-road
. On the 24th of March
William Wells
, a carrier, brought this trunk to my house, directed for Mr. Henry Turner, to be left at the Bell and Crown, public-house, Hoxton, until called for - on the Saturday morning the prisoner came and brought this note, (read) -

Mr. Turner will thank the landlord of the Bell and Crown to let the bearer have the box left by the Hoxton carrier - I consider him very neglectful in not leaving it at my house yesterday, as the young man told me it would be delivered by one o'clock yesterday.
Bath-street, March 24, 1831.

Directed to Mr. Walker, Bell and Crown, Kingsland-road. I said I thought it very strange, as two persons had been for it before, I would go and get the carrier - I went and got an officer, and when I came back the prisoner was gone; I saw him again in company with the officer - I let him have the trunk, and charged him 5s. 3d. for it; he said he was going to take it to the corner of the mad-house, but he wished us to go with him - I went on with him and the officer: as we were going on I said to the prisoner,"Suppose you don't meet the person you expect at the corner of the mad-house, where are you going to take the trunk?" he said, "I shall take it to No. 22, Bath-street, and ask for 1s.:" there was no man at the corner, and we went to No. 22, Bath-street - they said they knew nothing of the trunk nor the prisoner.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. He never varied in his account of the transaction? A. No - he said the man had given him 5s. 6d. to pay for the trunk; it was a half-crown and three shillings, and I gave him 3d. change; the trunk came on the Thursday; I had two persons apply for it on Friday - the prisoner came on Saturday; it should have been left at Hoxton before it arrived at my house - the prisoner did not state to me, on leaving my house, that he was going to get a bit of steak to have it dressed at the house; he did not return till he was brought back by the officer - I had told the officer a man had come for the box, and I told him to go and take care of it; I understood when the officer went there the prisoner went out, and he went after him - he found him about one hundred yards from the house; I saw him find him - he had no meat with him; I suppose I was about five minutes gone for the officer - I did not leave any one to take care of the prisoner; I said I was going for the carrier - the box was in the house at the time, but I believe the prisoner did not see it; it was before the box had been delivered to him, that I went for the officer - I then delivered him the box, for the purpose of seeing where he would take it; he then said he would not take it unless some one went with him.

HENRY TURNER
. I know this trunk - it contains articles belonging to a brother of mine, who is dead; I saw the trunk about two years ago - I expected the trunk and articles from Edinburgh.
NOT GUILTY .

946.
JAMES REYNOLDS
was indicted for
bigamy .

JAMES GOOD
. I am sexton, and assistant parish-clerk, at St. Bride's, in the city of London. I produce the register-book of the marriages in that parish - here is the register of the marriage of James Reynolds and
Ann Emery
, on the 7th of March, 1824; it is signed by the clergyman of the parish.
Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. I believe you were not in office at that time? A. No.

CHARLOTTE BUCKNEY
. I am the wife of
Thomas Buckney
- he is a grocer, and lives in York-street, Batter, sea-fields. I was present at the marriage of the prisoner and my sister Ann Emery; my name was then Charlotte Emery - the prisoner is the person who married her; she is alive, and is in Court now.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you known the prisoner before his marriage? A. yes, a few months.

SARAH CADBY
. I lived servant at No. 18, Upper Grosvenor-street. I was married to the prisoner on the 28th of December last, at St. George, Hanover-square.

Cross-examined. Q.How long had you known him? A. Six months or more - he told me he was a compositor, but he was a newspaper vender; I had no fortune - I did not know he had ever been married; I do not know
Joseph Bates
- I never told him, or said in his presence, that I knew the prisoner had been married; but after I was married a person said to me, "James Reynolds is married;""Yes, (said I) I know he is, he is married to me;" I nowlive with my father - I do not know that he threatened the prisoner with any violence; the prisoner put the marriage off once for three weeks - he said he wanted to go into the country.

COURT. Q. How long after you were married did you find out that he had been married? A. I suppose about two months - my father found it out, but I had gone into service before that, and the prisoner said he was going to live with his father.

JOSEPH CADBY
. I am the father of
Sarah Cadby
. I have a certificate of her marriage at St. George's, Hanover-square; I examined it with the book at the church - I took the prisoner on the 24th of February - (certificate read.)

Cross-examined. Q. I believe you have been some time a constable? A. Yes, but I had not the least idea of this till the 24th of February - my daughter went to service after the marriage, unknown to me; I never said I suspected the prisoner was married before this marriage - I only saw him twice before this marriage; he told me he was an apprentice, and did not wish his friends to know it; I asked him to step into a house, that I might look at him, and I said, "I think you are rather an old apprentice, and if I thought you were about to take any advantage of a child of mine, I should no more mind blowing out your brains than looking at you:" this was only a few nights before the marriage - I asked him for a reference, and he sent me to a place in Wych-street; they would not tell me much of him; and when I saw him again, he said the reason was that he was a natural child; I was going to the church to forbid the banns, but I was too late - I met them coming back.

SARAH CAMINI
. I accompanied Sarah Cadby when she was married to the prisoner, on the 28th of December, 1830.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 28. -
Confined One Year .

947.
RICHARD WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of March , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of a man unknown, from his person .

GEORGE DORRELL
. I am a brush-maker, and live in Carnaby-street. On the Thursday before the 17th of March, I was in Cleveland-row
; there was a great crowd- I saw the prisoner there - he attempted two or three persons' pockets before he succeeded in taking a handkerchief; I at last saw him take one from a gentleman's pocket, and put it into his own left-hand trousers pocket; I told Hobbs, who drew his hand out, with the handkerchief in it, before he had time to put it away.

Prisoner. Q. How far were you from me? A. Close to you; I told the officer as soon as I saw you take the handkerchief; You made no resistance - I unbuttoned your pocket, and threw out two handkerchiefs; the crowd was so great, it was impossible to get to the gentleman - I mentioned it to him, then on turning to secure you, I lost sight of him; the gentleman was not so tall as you, to the best of my recollection, not very stout, nor very thin; I believe he had a black body coat on - you were taken to the station-house, but no handkerchiefs were found on you there- I believe three or four were found on you in going along, besides the one you are indicted for; you told the Magistrate you should reserve what you had to say till another time - you was then committed for a week, on the evidence of Hobbs, myself, and another person, who picked up the handkerchief, but who was not bound over; the deposition was taken on the 17th of March - it made no difference to me whether you were committed on suspicion or not; I get my subsistence by working at my trade; I do not attend Police-offices - I did not know the officers; I did not say any such word as "Here is one, John;" when the Policemen got round you, I went back to find the gentleman, but he was gone; I do not know what I shall receive here - I did not say on the first examination that I apprehended you on suspicion; my name was put foremost at Clerkenwell Session, or I should not have prosecuted - I was examined as a witness.

THOMAS HOBBS
. I am a Police-constable. On the Thursday before the 17th of March I was on duty at the bottom of St. James'-street; I saw the prisoner, and watched him some time; he went up against gentlemen's pockets, and when he got thicker into the crowd, I saw him with the handkerchief in his hand, just behind a gentleman; I seized him, and pulled his hand out of his pocket, with the handkerchief in it - there were three other handkerchiefs found on him in going to the station-house, and a snuff-box; I said to him, "How came an old man like you to do this?" he said, "What is a poor fellow to do?"

Prisoner. Q. What reply did I make when you said to the other man, "I thought if I did not know him you would?" A. I never heard it said by myself or any one else; when I took hold of you I threw you into a clear place, and the only word I said to you was, "An old man like you, how came you to do it," and your reply was, "What is a poor fellow to do?" your right-hand pocket was ripped open, so that what was put into it might go down; the man you took it from might be rather stouter than you, and between thirty and forty he had a close body coat on; I cannot say what colour; I do not suppose he was more than two yards off you; no sooner had I seized you, than the swell mob came round to try to get you away, and we were surrounded by the Policemen: there were four handkerchiefs produced before the Magistrate - you were very likely committed to Tothill-fields, I do not know; the charge was for picking pockets.

Prisoner's Defence. I have not the means of procuring the document from the Police-office, and it appears now that your Lordship has only the second depositions; the depositions taken on the 10th of March were to the effect, solely that these men arrested me on suspicion, and found the handkerchiefs and snuff-box on my person - all the documents ought to be before your Lordship; and if a legal process takes place, and a man is put into prison, and brought before a superior tribunal, surely you will not hesitate to send for this first document; there it is in black and white, "Receive into your custody so and so, on suspicion of feloniously taking," &c.; cases of this nature are so common and notorious, that they have been scouted from Westminster-hall, and therefore it is that they have come here - these men have scouted the charge of suspicion, and now bring the charge of felony; and why or wherefore? because they found I was poor and friendless, or I should have discovered that the other was nothing but a common hireling, ready to come on any occasion; the difference to them is the difference of mygoing to prison, and the money they will get for coming here a second time and charging a felony; but will your Lordship upheld the doctrine, and countenance the practice that a man sworn to execute the law should one day apprehend a prisoner, and swear to one fact, and then a week afterwards swear to a contrary fact? Can two contrary facts both be true? one of them must necessarily be false-will your Lordship condescend to send for the depositions taken on the 10th of March, and also for the original warrant of commitment to Tothill-fields.

THOMAS HOBBS
re-examined. Q. Was the charge on suspicion of felony? A. Yes; I charged him with picking the pocket of a gentleman unknown - the Magistrate has sent all the depositions.

Prisoner. Surely your Lordship must wish to administer justice, and surely the delay of half an hour cannot be of importance. There is the document in the office, and here are twelve gentlemen come to swear that they will return a true verdict. If the Magistrate had done his duty, you would have had the depositions taken on 10th of March.
COURT. We have now got your commitment, and it is precisely in the form of the present charge, for stealing a handkerchief from a man unknown.

Prisoner. That is the reason why I asked if the whole four handkerchiefs were produced before the Magistrate, and I was charged on suspicion of them all - only a mere bailable charge; and you can have that evidence before you in half an hour; and surely, however depressed I may be, I have a right to justice. I hope your Lordship will send an officer for it, who is not interested in suppressing it.

JURY to
THOMAS HOBBS
. Q. How long have you known Dorrell? A. Very likely twelve months - I have seen him, but not to speak to him, before that day.

Prisoner to GEORGE DORRELL. Q. How long was it after you saw this taken that you seized me? A. Directly, and I prevented it from going to the bottom of your pocket-I do not know that I unbuttoned your pocket;I might pull your hand away from it - I did not feel your pocket.

Prisoner. If this doctrine is held forth that a witness may come one day and swear one fact, and another day a directly contrary fact, what individual could he safe? The witness charges me one day on suspicion of felony -I suspect he stole it" - and a week after he comes and days,"I charge him with stealing it; I saw him steal it." In the first instance more than half the truth was kept back, or in the second more than the truth was stated. I was passing the Green-park, saw a person look around him, and place something at the root of a tree; I pretended not to observe him; but when he went away, I went and found the handkerchiefs and a snuff-box - I went on, and was obstructed by the crowd; a hand pressed on my thigh, and a voice exclaimes, "John, here is one of them," the same person unbuttoned my pocket, and took out tow handkerchiefs, which I had put into that pocket, and I had two in the other pocket - I was then taken to the office, and there these men stated they arrested me on suspicion - the Magisrate asked if they had seen me take any thing; they said No. I do not know whether it was the same magistrate that I saw on the 17th, but if so, he had forgotten it, and I did not think it my business to put him in mind of it - they had in the interim found that I was poor and friendless, and they said, "Let us change the ground, and make a direct theft of it, and have a day or two's lounge-City fare is pretty good," and here they are, from the first day to the last or the last but one, and can any man be astonished that a man should come here to swear for 30s.or 40s, when it is well known that there are hundreds and thousands who will swear for half a crown.

GUILTY . Aged 56. -
Transported for Seven Years .
Fifth Middlesex Jury-before Mr. Common Sergeant

948.
JOHN HARRINGTON
was indicted for
feloniously forging a false request for delivery of goods , with intent to defraud
James Shoolbred
and
Gregory Cook
.
SECOND COUNT, for feloniously uttering the same.

SAMUEL CUTTER. I live with Messrs.
James Shoolbred
and
Gregory Cook
- they are haberdashers and linendrapers
, and live in Tottenham-court-road; they have a customer named Brewer-I know the prisoner, and have received three orders from him; I believe he was in the employ of Mr. Wyat, in whose family Miss Brewer lived as governess. On the 7th of March the prisoner brought this paper to my master's:-

MR. CUTTER. - If you have got seven yards in one piece of the same kind you sent on Saturday, but not to be entered to Mr. Wyat's account, I will pay for it on Wednesday, and about three skeins of silk to match it, tow sheets of wadding, and three yards of black ribbon half an inch in width; and if you can send the bill to-day, as we want to pay our quarter's bills.
March 7,1831. Miss BREWER.

In consequence of this I gave the prisoner the goods as near the order as possible - I had not seven yards of silk, so I sent a remnant of ten yards and a half; I had sent two yards and a half of black silk, and three-quarters of a yard of crimson on the Saturday - the ten and a half I sent was black, as that is a more general article; I also sent four skeins of sewing silk, and I think two sheets of wadding and three yards of black ribbon, half an inch wide, as ordered; I did that, believing the signature to be genuine, and the hand-writing of the lady who was governess in Mr. Wyat's family - I have many times before acted upon a written order from that lady; Mr. Wyat soner is the person who had the things.

JANE BREWER
. I am governess at Mr Wyat's, at Dudley-grove, Paddington. No part of this note is my writing, nor was it written by my authority - the prisoner was servant to Mr. Wyat, and I think was discharged about a month or six weeks ago; He had been there nine or ten months - Mr.Wyat is a sculptor, and the prisoner was his errand-boy; I believe he bore an honest character - he was discharged before the day in question.

CHARLES MAINE
. This black silk was pawned with me on the 7th of March for 1l. 2s. and, to the best of my belief, by the prisoner; this is the counterpart of the duplicate - there are ten yards and a half of it.

GEORGE McGREGER
. I am a Police-constable. I took the prisoner on the 7th of March - I found this sewing silk an ribbon in his pocket; he had come back to the prosecutor's shop for more goods.

SAMUEL CUTTER
. I know this silk from the length.and from the prisoner stating where he had pawned it -I went there, and found it; it corresponds in quality - I believe this sewing silk and ribbon to be what I gave according to the order.

JURY. Q. What time was the order produced? A. About half - past nine or ten o'clock on Monday morning; Miss Brewer did not keep a separate account - it was entered to Mr, Wyat, as he discharged any thing that Miss Brewer had.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Confined Two Years .

949.
MICHAEL WALDON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of March , 1 plane, value 3s. , the goods of
Thomas Martin
.

THOMAS MARTIN
. I live in Lower-street, Islington, and am a carpenter . On the 12th of March I lost a plane from my bench, in an unfinished house in Chadwell-street
- I left it safe at dinner-time, and did not miss it till about four o'clock; the prisoner was employed on the same premises - this is the plane.

HENRY FOWLER
. I the service of Mr. Cordwell, a pawnbroker, in Exmouth-street, on the 12th of March the prisoner brought this plane to out shop - he pawned it for 6d, in the name of John Davies, for his father; he came twice to the shop with it.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you not on the first occasion doubt whether this was the person?

A. I did not recognize him in the first instance, but that was on a different charge; his brother was brought up, and while he was gone for his brother another person asked if I knew him, and I said No - there is a brotherly likeness between them; I believe he is older, but not so tall- I did not express a doubt whether the prisoner was the person who pawned the plane; I did not entertain any doubt about that.
THOMAS LOW. I am a constable. I took the prisoner into custody.
Prisoner's Defence. The pawnbroker said when I went with my brother, that I was the lad who pawned it. and I was not - he said I went there between three and five O'clock.

THOMAS MARTIN
re-examined. Q. Did you know the prisoner's brother? A. Yes - he never worked there but one day, which was after the 12th of March, when his brother was ill - I think the pawnbroker's shop is half a mile from where I worked.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 19.

Recommended to Mercy by the Jury. -
Confined 1 Month .

950.
GEORGE THOMPSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of March , 1 tea-kettle, value 1s,6d. the goods of
Richard Jones
.

WRIGHT WOODHOUSE
. I live with Mr. Richard Jones - he keeps a public-house at the corner of Plumtree-street and Broad-street, St. Giles'. I used the tea-kettle on the 28th of March, about seven o'clock in the morning; the prisoner came in about that time - I missed the kettle between half-past seven and eight o'clock; I had put it down by the side of the pump, in the corner, over the counter - I went on with my work, and when I came to look for the kettle, I missed it.

WILLIAM HARRIS
. I am a Police-constable. On the 28th of March a latl came running to me from a shop to take a man with a kettle; I went to take him for stealing other things-he had this kettle, which he said was given to him by woman to sell for 1s.
JURY. Q. Had he the kettle in his hand? A. No - it was on the counter, where he offered it for sale; it was stated in his presence that he had offered it.(Properly produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defenee. A woman met me at the corner of George-street, and asked me to sell this kettle for her - I went to try to sell it, and the woman sent for the officer.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Confined Six Months .

951.
JOHN SCARFE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of March , 1 pair of shoes, value 6s. , the goods of
Clara Collyer
.

WILLIAM SIBLEY
. I am a Police-constable. On the 24th of March I saw the prisoner and another man in St. Martin's-court - I watched them for three-quarters of an hour; they were dressed very shabby, and were looking into respectable shops; I told the prisoner to go away - he went one way and I went the other; there were two persons going the same way as he was - I saw him go to the prosecutrix's shop, take these shoes, and put them under his arm - I took him with them.

CLARA COLLYER
. I am single . I keep a boot and shoe-shop in St. Martin's-court
. The officer brought the prisoner and the shoes to my shop about five o'clock - they are mine, and are worth 6s; I had seen them safe about half an hour before.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Seven Years .

952.
GEORGE STONE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of February , 2 loaves of bread, value 1s. 4d. the goods of
John Elwin
.

ARN ELWIN. I am the wife of John Elwin - he lives in Wellington-street, Bethnal-green
, and is a baker , On the 25th of February I was in a little room which joins the shop - there is a glass window between them; I saw the prisoner, who had just taken two loaves from the window, and was walking out with them - I opened the door, and called to him; he put them on the threshold, and ran away - I am quite sure he is the person; Mr Gardiner brought him back - put the same loaves on the counter, and the policeman took them.

EDMUND GARDINER. I live in Wellington-street, Bethnal-green. On the 25th of February I was in Selby-street - the prosecutor's shop is at the corner; I saw the prisoner running fast from their door - the prosecutrix came to the shop, and called to me to stop him, which I did.
MICHAEL JOURDAN. I am a Police-constable. I was sent for, and took the prisoner - I received two loaves from the prosecutrix and her husband.
Jury to ANN ELWIN. Q. Was the prisoner in the habit of coming to the shop? A. No - I thought I had seen him pass the door.
GUILTY. Aged 17.
Recommended to mercy by the Jury.

Judgment Respited
.

953.
CHARLES ROBERTS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of February , 1 jacket, value 5s., and 1 pair of trousers, value 6s., the goods of
William Hall
, from the person of
Henry Hall
.

DAVID DILLON
. I am six years and a half old - I go to church sometimes; I live with my father, in Norwich-court, Fetter-lane. I remember playing with Henry Hall at the corner of Graystoke-place - the prisoner came, and told Henry Hall to go and find his donkey; he went, and the prisoner went after him - when they got to the top of Fetter-lane, I saw the prisoner take Henry Hall on his shoulder, and he went away; Hall had his clothes on then, his pinafore, shoes and stockings - I saw him in the evening when he came home; he had only his shirt, shoes and pinafore, and his sister's pelisse on - the prisoner had a black coat on at first; when I saw him again he had a white coat.

WILLIAM HALL
. I live at No. 2, Norwich-court, and am an ornamental painter - my son Henry in six years old.
