I saw him on the 14th of February; he had on his stockings, his boots, a shirt, a suit of cloth clothes, a pinafore over them, and a cap; I lost sight of him about two o'clock when I went to my business, and did not return till five -I saw my son again about six o'clock: he then had on his stockings, his boots, a pinafore, and his sister's pelisse, which was sent to fetch him home in; his suit of clothes were gone.
Prisoner. Q. Did you ever see me? A. Not to my knowledge.

GEORGE HALL
. I saw my brother at dinner time, with a dark suit of clothes on - he was playing in the court at one o'clock; I afterwards went to the White Horse, in Twister's-alley, Whitecross-street - I saw him there in the kitchen, without jacket or trousers on; I brought him home.

SUSAN SEVERIDGE
. I am the wife of Anthony Severidge, of Graham's-building, Blue Anchor-alley, Bunhill-row. I found Henry Hall on the Monday, in the privy of the yard belonging to the apartment - he had only his shirt, shoes, and stockings on, and his cap and pinafore in his hand; I took him in doors, and he told me where his parents lived - this was about four o'clock, and I suppose a mile and a half from his parents.
NOT GUILTY . (See page 416.)

954.
ANN PRITCHARD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of February , 1 bonnet, value 5s. , the goods of
Edward Barringer
.

EDWARD BARRINGER
. I live in Dean-street, Westminster
- my wife keeps a bonnet-shop. On the afternoon of the 24th of February I missed a bonnet, between three and four o'clock, which I had seen safe at two; I went to Orchard-street, and saw the prisoner with the bonnet on.

WILLIAM SCHOFIELD
. I am a plumber, and live in Dean-street. On the 24th of February I saw the prisoner pass my shop, and go into the prosecutor's; she came out with such a bonnet as this - I believe it to be the same.

THOMAS CREA
. I am a Police-constable. About three o'clock, on the 24th of February, the prisoner was given to me by the prosecutor.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that she was intoxicated, and had found the bonnet on the floor.

GUILTY . Aged 57. -
Confined One Month .

955.
RICHARD TRINDELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of March , 1 jacket, value 2s., and 1 pair of trousers, value 2s. , the goods of
John Sedwell
.

JOHN SEDWELL
. I am a gunner in the Royal Artillery; I occupy the adjoining room to Doubleday (see the next case.)I left it between two and three o'clock, and my box was safe - I returned at eight in the evening, and missed my stable-dress, a pair of trousers, a jacket, and waistcoat.

DANIEL RIERDON
. I am a Police-constable. I found the jacket and trousers on the prisoner at the New - way watch-house on the 31st of March.(Property produced and sworn 10.)
Prisoner's Defence. I bought these things of a man for 3s, as I was going to Greenwich, at half-past seven or near eight o'clock on Sunday night.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Transported for Seven years .

956.
JAMES TURNEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of March , 1 watch, value 2l., and 1 handkerchief, value 1s. , the goods of
Henry Doubleday
.

HENRY DOUBLEADAY
. I am a private in the Royal Artillery ; the prisoner belonged to the same corps, and lodged in the same room at Woolwich
. On the 13th of March I went out, and left a silver watch, wrapped up in a white shirt, in my box- I returned about eight o'clock, and missed my watch and 5s.6d. in money; the prisoner was than missing - I saw him in about four days afterwards, at Woolwich; I lost two double handkerchiefs - I had left the money in my knapsack; no one was present when I put it away.

THOMAS RIDPATH
. I am a pawnbroker, in Upper Seymour-street, Euston-square. The watch was pawned with me on the 19th of March, by Thomas Hintridge for 17s.

THOMAS HINTRIDGE
. I live at the Southampton Arms, Camden-town. The prisoner came into the room, and had a pot of porter - he offered a watch for sale, and asked 25s. for it; I offered him 1s - he said he would not take 1l., he could pawn it for that; he went out, and the next day he returned, produced a duplicate, and offered it me for half a crown - I gave him 1s. 6d.for it; I sent
Richard Griffin
for the watch.

RICHARD GRIFFIN
. I received the duplicate - I went to Battle-bridge, and took the watch out of pawn, for a guinea and 6d; I gave it to Hintridge.

THOMAS HINTRIDGE
. I kept it two days, and then pawned it for 17s. at Mr. Ridpath's.

HENRY DOUBLEDAY
. I can swear to this handkerchief by the pattern and colour - I know the watch by two cracks on the face; I have worn it some years.
Q. When did you see it again? A. on Wednesday last, and I lost it a month ago last Sunday - it has two seals and a key, which I know.

GUILTY . Aged 23 -
Transported for Seven years .

957.
CAROLINE STEVENS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of March , 1 pocket-book, value 2d.; 1 needle-case, value 1d.; 1 cap, value 1s. 6d.; 1 lock and key,value 9d; 2 shillings, 2sixpences, and 12 penny-pieces, the property of
John Lynch
, from the person of Sarah, his wife .

SARAH LYNCH
. I am the wife of
John Lynch
- we live in Riding-house-lane, Great Titchfield-street. On the 29th of March, I was at the Two Brewers, Great St. Andrew-street, Seven-dials
- my husband and I had a little difference, and he knocked my cap off; I left him, and went to a doctor to have my head dressed - while I was at the public-house, the prisoner came up to the door; she asked what was the matter - I told her to put my bonnet and cap on my head; she took my lace cap, and put a dirty night-cap on my head - I had not been drinking freely: we had had a pint of beer - I had handed my pocket to my little girl - It had in it four duplicates, the key of my door, a pocket - book, four shillings, two sixpences, some copper, and a needle-case; she is not five years old - I gave it her to hold while I rolled up my hair; I saw the Prisoner snatch it from the child and run away.

Prisoner. Q. Did you not treat me to some gin? A. No - I gave her 3d. after she put the bonnet on my head; I did not then know she had changed my cap - my husband and I were not throwing the pocket at each other.

WILLIAM JACKSON
. I am a Police-constable. I took the prisoner, and some other persons on the 29th of March- she was at a public-house, at the corner of Monmouth-street; she dropped a needle-case and a pocket-book, which I took up after wards - I then saw her drop the key of the prosecutor's door; I did not find the cap.

Prisoner. I had nothing to do with the key - she was throwing the pocket at her husband, and Mary Riley put her bonnet and cap on; I asked if I should take her little girl to her husband, as she was so much intoxicated.

WILLIAM JACKSON
. She was not intoxicated.

SARAH LYNCH
. This is the night-cap, but I had had on a lace cap, drawn with pink ribbons, and two rows of edging.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY of stealing the needle-case, pocket-book, and key . Aged 26. -
Confined one month .

958.
WILLIAM STRIDE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of April , 10 window-sashes, value 50s. , the goods of
Andrew Germain
and another.

HENRY SWAIN
. I am a Police-constable. On the morning of the 5th of April I saw some sashes behind a caravan, in the road near the Small Pox-hospital - Souter was standing by them; I afterwards saw the prisoner and Minifi, who were in conversation, but I could not tell what they said; I went up, and took the prisoner and Souter - the prisoner said he had bought the sashes on the 4th of April, at a sale over the water, but he could not tell the place, or the auctioneer's name - he gave me his address, which I found correct; the people said he had lived there eight months, but they did not know how he got his living.
Cross-examined by MR. STURGEON. Q. It is not an uncommon thing to have sales over the water? A. No; I did not see the sashes in any cart.

CHARLES SOUTER
. I am porter, and lodge in King-street, Borough. On the 4th of April I was standing to be hired at London-bridge; the prisoner came and engaged me to carry some sash-frames to Battle-bridge the next morning, and the next morning, at half-past five, or a quarter before six o'clock, he took me to Joiner-street, Tooley-street - there were gates and a yard there; the bar was down - the prisoner opened the gates; I saw these sashframes there, on a tank, and the prisoner helped them on my knot - I carried them; I asked him whether I should go over London-bridge, as that was the nearest way, but he said he wanted to go to the Borough-market - I went on, he with me, and when we got to a joiner's shop, I pitched them down, and untied them - he went to a man named Minifi; the Policeman came, and took me and the prisoner.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.Then you were taken as well as the prisoner? A. Yes; I said he took them out of the yard, and so he did - I was not afraid I should be tried; I am a jobbing porter - I hand known the prisoner before; he had not paid me - I often do jobs without knowing what I shall have for them: the sashes were all tied up when he opened the gates, and he took them.

THOMAS MINIFI
. I live at No.14, Battle-bridge, and am a glazier. The prisoner came to my house on the morning of the 5th of April, about eight o'clock, and asked if I wanted to buy some old windows; I said I did not know that I did, but where were they - he said, "Over here;" I went to look at them, and had some conversation with him - I said they did not suit me; the Policeman came up just as I left them.

PETER PAYTON
. I am in the service of Mr. Andrew Germain and Mr. Fletcher - they are iron-merchants , and live in Iron-yard, Tooley-street
. I have seen these ten sashes - they are my masters; I cannot tell what they are worth - they had been kept in the first floor warehouse near the counting - house; there was a considerable quantity of goods there, and these were behind the other things I went about ten o'clock in the morning of the 5th of April, and missed them; there was a lock on the back gate adjoining Joiner-street, and that had been forced, and then they must have crossed the premises; I should not have known how the gate could have been opened after the lock was off, till the Policeman showed me how the chain could be slipped over the bar; I had no suspicion of the sashes being lost till the policeman came - they would have been in the loft for twelve months; there was nothing removed on the Monday evening.

Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. Were they new sashes? A. No, old ones, purchased at the old buildings in a street adjoining Tolley-street, some months ago - I do not know when; I had seen them in the loft very likely a month before - there were three blank panes in one of them- I have seen the prisoner at the premises - he came and said he was doing business for this gentleman, and that gentleman; he came there under pretence of buying, and laid out perhaps a few pence - I took his money, but it was very little.

PHILIP ROGERS
. I am a carpenter, and live in Watney-street. I have looked at these sashes, and know them - I was employed to by them, and take them out; they were put into a loft on the prosecutors' premises - there is an entrance from joiner-street, and gates to the yard; there is an iron tank there.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You did not make these sashes? A. No, they are old ones - I know them by this moulding, and this little leaden light, which opens; you will not find another sash mended like this in London - I had observed it in those I bought.

GUILTY . Aged 38. -
Confined Six Months .
OLD COURT. WEDNESDAY, APRIL 13.
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

959.
THOMAS HAYES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of April , 7 pieces of leather, value 5s. , the goods of
Robert Bryan
and others; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . -
Confined Three Months .

960.
ELIZABETH CANE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of April , 3 shifts, value 25s., and 2 handkerchiefs, value 4s. , the goods of
Edward Cornelius Cooper
, her master.

LILLY COOPER
. I am the wife of Edward Cornelius Cooper - we live in King-square
; the prisoner was six weeks in our service. On Wednesday evening last a lodger on the first floor missed a sovereign; I suspected the prisoner, and asked if she would allow me to see her box - she put it on the floor, lifted up the lid herself, and I found in it a lawn handkerchief of my own, and two duplicates of the other articles - I asked her where she got the articles which were pawned - she said she found them in the street; my husband sent for an officer.

TIMOTHY DONOVAN
. I am a watchman of King-square. I took the prisoner to the station-house; the handkerchiefs and duplicates were found, and given to me.

NATHANIEL NICHOLLS
. I am a Policeman. I received the prisoner in charge at the station, with the duplicates and property.

JOSEPH AVANT
. I live with Mr. Gray, in Fleet-street. I received these two shifts in pawn - I do not know who from, but this is the duplicate I gave the person.

FREDERICK JAMES
. I live with Mr. Bath, a pawnbroker, in Goswell-street. I have a shift and silk handkerchief, pawned by a person, to whom I gave this duplicate - I cannot swear who it was.(Property produced and sworn to)
Prisoner. I meant to get them out of pawn.
GUILTY . Aged 15.
MRS. COOPER. I believe she stole the sovereign out of the lodger's purse.
Transported for Seven Years .

961.
SARAH WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of April , 1 bonnet, value 6d.; 1 shawl, value 6d.; 1 pair of shoes, value 2s.; 1 pair of pattens, value 6d.; and 1 handkerchief, value 1s. the goods of
Michael Mack
.

CATHERINE MACK
. I am the wife of
Michael Mack
, we live in Mulberry-row, Carnaby-market
. On the 8th of April, about four o'clock in the afternoon, I was at the White Bear public-house - I had been taken ill at my work, went in there and sat down; the prisoner came in and sat by me - I had never seen her before - I had half a pint of beer in my hand - she was kind to me, and said she would see me home; I declined that; she offered again, and went home with me to my lodgings - she said I had better lay down as I was poorly; I did so, and fell asleep, leaving her to mind the room - I awoke in about an hour and she was gone - I missed my bonnet and these other things off a line - I found her about eight o'clock the next night, sitting in the same public-house, with my bonnet on; she said she had bought it of me, and had left her own in the room - there was no bonnet left there - I have found nothing else.

WILLIAM GIBBS
. I am a porter. The prosecutrix fetched me to the public-house - I took the prisoner to the watch-house with this bonnet on her head.

Prisoner's Defence. There were ten or a dozen people saw me buy the bonnet of her at the public-house - I put it on, and she wore mine - the Magistrate sent her to see if it was not at her lodging, but she had made away with it - when I took her home her husband was there; he said he wished I had not brought her, for she was a drunken beast and made away with every thing.

CATHERINE MACK
. I was not drunk, but quite ill - my husband came home and went out, leaving her there.
WILLIAM GIBBS. Directly I took the prisoner, she said she had bought the bonnet of her, and had seen nothing of the other things.
NOT GUILTY .

962
JOHN BRADBEAR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of March , 4 saws, value 9s.; 5 planes, value 10s.; 1 square, value 1s.; 1 stock, value 4s.; and 1 rule, value 1s. , the goods of
Joseph Skinner
.

JOSEPH SKINNER
. I am a carpenter , and live in the Hampstead-road. The prisoner has worked for me, off and on, for seven or eight years - I have missed various tools, and gave him in charge last July, for stealing a stock, but could not trace it to him - I still continued to miss tools, and the week before I gave him in charge, he acknowledged having stolen 2 saws, and promised to redeem them - I discharged him, but he did not leave - I found him in my kitchen on Sunday morning, drunk, and gave him in charge - my rule and duplicates for several tools were found on him - I found a quantity of my property at the pawnbroker's.
HENRY EAST. I am an officer. I found a number of duplicates on the prisoner; one was for a plane.

RICHARD HAYWARD. I am an apprentice to Mr. Fletcher. I have two planes, pawned in the name of
John Wilby
- the duplicate I gave the person is among those found on the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 39.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Three Months .

963.
CATHERINE GREEN , alias COCKBURN
, was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of April , three 5l. Bank notes, the property of
John Williams
, from his person .
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

964.
DANIEL DONOGHUE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of April , 1 silver spoon, value 4s. , the goods of
Samuel Burchfield
.

SAMUEL BURCHFIELD
. I am a rope-maker , and live at Poplar
; the prisoner was in my service. On the 3rd of April - the Policeman came to my house with a spoon, which I believe to be mine - I have brought one here, which corresponds with it - I understood from my servantthat one was missing, but she is not here - the prisoner was in the habit of coming into the house at times - he had been two or three years in my employ.

WILLIAM REEVES
. I am a Policeman. On the 4th of April I was fetched to Mr. Young's - he gave the prisoner in charge, with this spoon - I asked how he came by it - he said he had been playing at buttons and marbles with some boys in Limehouse-causeway, and gave the buttons and marbles he had won of them, with 2d., for the spoon - he said he did not know the boys.

ROBERT YOUNG
. I am a pawnbroker. On the 4th of April the prisoner came to my shop, and offered this spoon to pawn; I asked who he brought it from; he said from his mother - he gave several accounts about it, and at last I said, "I suppose you brought it from some boy?" - he said he did, and I gave him in charge.

SAMUEL BURCHFIELD
. My initials are on the spoon -I have one here marked the same way, and I believe it to be mine - I always found the prisoner honest.
Prisoner's Defence. I played with some boys, and won some marbles of them - they asked me to buy the spoon; I gave the marbles and 2d. for it.

GUILTY. Aged 13. -
Judgment Respited
.

965.
JOHN HADISTON
and
PETER GARRATY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of March , 1 grafting-tool, value 4s. , the goods of
James Layton
.

PETER DANIELS
. I and the prisoners are navigators
- they worked in the same field as me, but not at the same spot. Layton left this tool with me about seven o'clock on Saturday evening, and I put it under the stairs at the Falcon public-house, Stoke Newington
, where I sleep - I missed it about half-past six on Sunday evening - the prisoners were drinking in the tap-room; I went to them and said, "It is very strange you should go into the place and take the tool; it must be somebody who is in the house;" Hadiston followed me outside the door and said, "If you say we stole the tool I will smash you," (holding up his clenched fist) - I said I did not say it was them, but it must be somebody in the house.

DANIEL DAWSON
. I keep a retail beer-shop in Stoke Newington. The two prisoner came into the passage leading to my tap-room, in company - I asked what they wanted, they said the boy I employed to take out the beer- I said he was gone out, and asked what they wanted of him - one of them (I don't know which) said, to leave this tool till Monday morning - I said I would take care of it, as they used my house.

JOSEPH MARSHALL
. I am a Police-constable. I apprehended the prisoners on the 28th of March; they said nothing to me.

EDWARD FREEMAN
. I got the tool from the beer-shop- I have had it ever since.

JAMES LAYTON
. This is my tool; I left it in Daniel's care.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How do you know it? A. It is marked with a piece of wire at each end - I never asked for 30s. not to prosecute -
Thomas McBride
came to me and offered me 30s., but I never asked him for it - I do not know whether any body else was present. but nobody can say I asked him for the money.
Hadiston's Defence. I am innocent.

THOMAS McBRIDE
. I offered to settle this with Layton - he asked me 5l. at first - he told me if I would not give that before he went before the Magistrate, he would prosecute the men - there had been a subscription raised among their friends.

COURT. Q. Did Daniels or Layton want to make it up? - A.Daniels wanted 7s. for two days' work, and Layton wanted 30s. - they had been before the Magistrate once - the prisoners knew themselves innocent, and did not wish the money to be given, but our mates subscribed 30s. - we could not afford to raise 5l. - he afterwards said he would take 30s., which we put into the hands of Mr. Hudson - he said he would keep away from the Magistrate for 3s. 6d. a day.

JURY to
PETER DANIELS
. Q. Did you find the tool at a different house to where you lost it from? A. Yes, I found it at a beer-shop one hundred and fifty yards off.

HADISTON -
GUILTY . Aged 29.
Confined Three Weeks .

GARRATY -
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Confined Seven Days .

966.
JOSEPH JORDAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of February , 1 coat, value 10s., and 1 pair of boots, value 10s. , the goods of
Robert Proctor
.

SARAH FOX. I am servant to Mr. Proctor, of Perceval-street
. On the 22nd of February we were having wine in, between six and seven o'clock in the evening - my master desired me to stand at the street-door, which was open, while it was brought in, and as I went up, I saw a man going out of the passage with a coat and pair of shoes, which were taken out of the hall - I gave an alarm; my master went out, and took him.
Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q.How far off was he taken? A. About twenty yards - I did not lose sight of him; the boots were not found, but I saw him with them as well as the coat.

ROBERT PROCTOR. I was coming out of my dining-room, and the servant said, "There is a man run away with your boots;" she pointed out the prisoner, who was running about twenty yards off - I ran, took him into a shop, and said, "Where are my boots?" he said, "I have no boots of your's;" he was very uneasy, and shuffling a coat off his back; I found he had my coat on over his own; it was rather dusky - he kept shaking his arms as he ran, and I suppose he was then putting the coat on - the boots have not been found.

GUILTY . Aged 23. -
Transported for Seven Years .

967.
MARY WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of April , 1 gown, value 2s., and 1 tippet, value 1s., the goods of
Caroline Wilson
; and 2 gowns, value 3s. , the goods of
Jane Anderson
.
The prosecutrixs did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

968.
MARTIN McNORTY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of April , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
John Fenwick
, from his person .

JOHN FENWICK
. I am a silk-mercer , and live in the Regent-circus. On the 6th of April, about eleven o'clock in the morning, I was in Holborn
; I felt a pull at my pocket, and missed my handkerchief; I turned round, and saw the prisoner close to my elbows - I followed him a fewpaces; the Policeman came up, and took him by my desire - I said he had my handkerchief; he denied it - I saw it found in his trousers pocket.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Whipped and Discharged.

969.
WILLIAM WALKER
was indicted for
embezzlement .

THOMAS DINSDALE
. I am an agent and clerk at St. Katharine's-wharf - the prisoner was occasionally my agent, or servant ; I paid him as he worked. Some rags were sent to me for sale; he told me he had sold them to Rackley for 19l. 6s. 1d., according to their weight - I gave him a note to Rackley for the money; I had sent the goods by my team on the 31st of March, about twelve o'clock in the day, and was to have the money back the same day; I authorized the prisoner to receive it for me- I had paid him 6s. that day for previous work which he had done; he never brought me the money - I told him to bring it to me or my employer; I did not see him again till the morning following, when I went with an officer, and took him out of bed.
Prisoner. Mr. Dinsdale received 1l. on account. Witness. I received 1l. from Rackley the day previous to his getting the money; I got it to pay the prisoner the 6s.

JOHN RACKLEY
. I bought the rags of the prisoner as agent for Dinsdale - they came to 19l. 6s. 1d.; I had paid 1l. on account, and paid the prisoner 18l. 6s. 1d. on the 31st of March - here is a receipt which he signed for it in my presence (read); I paid him the whole amount, but finding 1l. had been paid, he returned that to me.
MR. DINSDALE. He was to take the money to my employer if I was not in the way - I have not received any of it.

Prisoner's Defence I received it on Good Friday, and on Saturday was going down to pay Mr. Dinsdale -I got intoxicated, and was robbed on Saturday evening; on Sunday morning I took the party who robbed me to the station-house in Wellclose-square; I was to appear against them at Lambeth-street on Monday, but Mr. Dinsdale came with an officer and took me out of bed.

MR. DINSDALE. After he was apprehended, he took a German there who could not speak English, and said he had robbed him; the Magistrate was three hours investigating the case, and then said there was not the least charge against the man, and I must prosecute the prisoner - the prisoner said the man and him bad had a glass of rum together, and that ten or twelve people were in the house when he was robbed, but it was proved he was not robbed at all.

GUILTY . Aged 45. -
Transported for Seven Years .

970.
SARAH BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of April , 1 sheet, value 7s., and 1 spoon, value 2s., the goods of
John Gibson
; and 1 spoon, value 2s. , the goods of
Ann Garlick
.

ANN DUTT
. I live in Hornsey-row, Islington
. Mr. John Gibson and
Ann Garlick
lodge with me - the prisoner had been rather better than twelve months in Mr. Gibson's service; I had reason to suspect her - the officer searched her box on the 3rd on the April, and found several duplicates.

JOHN NEAL
. I am a Policeman. I found six duplicates in the prisoner's box, one for a shirt and a spoon, and I found duplicates of five more spoons on her person.
GEORGE STOWELL. I am a pawnbroker, and live at Islington. I have a shirt and two spoons, pawned by the prisoner at different times.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor and Jury.
Confined Three Months .

971.
THOMAS SMITH
was indicted for
a misdemeanor .
NOT GUILTY .
NEW COURT. WEDNESDAY, APRIL 13.
Fifth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

972.
JAMES SMITH
was indicted for
bigamy .

DANIEL HONE
. I live in Castle-street, Bloomsbury - I am a hair-dresser. I went to the parish church of St. Martin in the Fields, with the prisoner, my wife, and another person - the prisoner was there married to my sister,
Elizabeth Hone
; she was at that time single - she is still alive; they lived together till last Spring - I think in April last he left her.

SUSAN TIBBS ROWEL
. I live in George-street, Portman Chapel. I have known the prisoner two years last August - I understood him to be single, and that he was living in Marylebone-lane; I went to Christchurch, Spitalfields, with him on the 25th of last May - we were married there; the pew-opener and the clerk were present - I was married in the name of
Susan Rowel
; a friend of mine heard the prisoner was married, while I was in the country with him, at Overton, in Hampshire, and when I came to town, seven weeks or two months after we were married, I heard of it.

Prisoner. I was with her drinking in Tottenham-court-road, two or three days before I was married, I got nearly tipsy, and I told her I was married. Witness. No, he did not - I never knew it; I have been with him there several times, and have taken a glass of ale, but have never been intoxicated - he never told me he was married.

Prisoner. I told her the very day, that I had not money to provide for the marriage, and she had better put it off to a future time. Witness. I did pay for the marriage, but I never understood he wished to put it off - I was living in Carpenter's-buildings, London-wall, in service, up to the day of the marriage.

Prisoner. After we came to London she agreed to go to service; I got work at Cambridge - she heard where I was, and, as she was in the family-way, came down to me; being out of a situation I came to London, and she agreed to go to her aunt's - while she was there she was confined. Witness. I had a child on the 19th of January - I did not go to him without his sending for me.

Prisoner. I lived very comfortably with my first wife, and she proved a very good one till we removed to Westminster, when she got acquainted with a man named Mettel - she used to go out with him, and get intoxicated - she came to me, and took away the money I had to provide Counsel with, and left me without; she had this
Susan Rowel
with her at the time - she told me therewould he no trial, for they would keep away; I have no witnesses on that account.

GUILTY . Aged 36. -
Confined One Year .

973.
WILLIAM GEORGE SHARP
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of February , 1 pair of graining-plates, value 1l. , the goods of
William Crawford
.

WILLIAM CRAWFORD
. I live in Walbrook-buildings, Hoxton, and am assistant to my father. Mr. William Crawford, of Peerless-row, a book-binder . On the 16th of February the prisoner came to my father, and asked for the loan of a pair of quarto morocco graining-plates for Mr. Knock - I lent them to him, and he never returned them.

GEORGE KNAPP
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Golden-lane. On the 16th of February the prisoner brought two pairs of graining-plates, which he said he had brought for his father, whose name was James Sanders, No. 13, Whitecross-street, and his own name was John Sanders.

JOHN KNOCK
. The prisoner was my apprentice , and left me on the 23rd of January - I did not send him to Mr. Crawford's to borrow any thing on the 16th of February.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I hope you will be as favourable as you can.
GUILTY . Aged 16.

974.
WILLIAM GEORGE SHARP
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of February , 1 pair of graining-plates, value 25s. , the goods of
Alexander Crawford
.

ALEXANDER CHAWFORD
. I live in Peerless-row. The prisoner came to my house on the 16th of February, and borrowed a pair of morocco graining-plates for Mr. Knock - I let him have them; these are them.
Prisoner. Q.Did you not say you gave me the plates? A. Yes, I gave them into your hand, as you stood at the door, for your master.
COURT. Q. You did not intend to part with the property? A.Certainly not, only to lend them to his master - he had borrowed them for him before.

GEORGE KNAPP
. I took these plates in pawn with the others, and lent 2s. on them.
GUILTY . Aged 16.

Confined Three Months , and
Whipped .

975.
ELIZA HURRY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of March , 3 half-crowns, and 1 crown, the monies of
John Gardiner
, from his person .

JOHN GARDINER
. I live in Lamb-alley, Bermondsey-street, and am a skinner . On the 6th of March I went to a public-house in Wentworth-street - I had a pint or two of beer; I asked for a bed, and they could not let me have one, but recommended me to a private house just by - I went there, and went to bed; I counted what money I had before I went to bed; I had two crowns and three half-crowns, and I put them into my trousers pocket - there was a candle in the room; when I had been in bed about twenty minutes, I saw a woman come into the room with nothing on her but her shift - she came to my bed-side; I asked what she wanted - she said to come to bed to me; I had placed my trousers, with my money in them, under my head, but when I looked round I saw them on the floor, near to the prisoner - I got out of bed, examined my trousers pockets, and missed the three half-crowns and one of the 5s. pieces; I accused the prisoner of robbing me - she could not speak, on account of having something in her mouth; I seized her, and in the scuffle the candle went out - I called the people of the house, and sent for a Policeman; when he was coming up the stairs the prisoner put a crown-piece and a half-crown into my hand, and said she would make it all up before the Policeman came - I said I would not till she gave me the other two half-crowns; I saw she had something in her mouth - I seized her throat, and grappled with her, but I have never seen the other two half-crowns since; I detained her till the officer came in- I had had a pint or two of beer, just to refresh myself.

Prisoner. I was in bed when he came into the house; he asked if there was any woman in the house - he heard me cough, and said, "That is a woman's voice." Witness. No, I did not; I did not get out of bed and let her in in her shift.
COURT. Q.How came you to go there for a bed? A. I had been to some friends, then went to the public-house, and as I felt myself fatigued I thought I would get a bed there.

Prisoner. Did I not say, "If you think I have any money, where have I got to put it?" and then you asked the woman to send for an officer; I did not offer to go away - I did not put this money into your hand. Witness. Yes, you put the money in my hand in the dark.

JURY. Q.What hour was it? A. A quarter before eight o'clock - I had never seen the prisoner before, and did not know she was in the house till she came to my bed-side; I suspected it was a house of ill-fame when I got into it, and that made me count my money - I never was in the house before; I am not married.

JAMES WALTON
. I am a Police-constable. On the night of the 6th of March I was in Wentworth-street; I was called, and went to the house, where I found the prisoner and the prosecutor on the second floor - the prosecutor was standing in his shirt, and the prisoner in her shift; I took a light with me - there was no light in the room; the prosecutor said she had robbed him of 12s. 6d. - he held out his hands, and said, "Here is what she has given me back," holding a crown-piece in one of his hands, and a half-crown in the other - I took the prisoner to the station-house, but found nothing on her; the prosecutor appeared sensible of what was going on - there was a partition between the room his bed was in and the other; that house makes up from seventy to eighty beds- they are all in narrow slips; the partitions only go up about six or seven feet high - it is more like a rabbit-warren than any thing else; any person might throw any thing over the partition; I have had several charges from that house.
JURY. Q. What is the sign of the public-house? A. The Two Brewers.

HENRY MARQUARD
. I was with Walton - I received the crown and half-crown; we could not find any more -I did not observe that there had been a candle in the room, which had been put out.
Prisoner's Defence. He had been drinking - heowned himself he was drinking with another female at the corner.

JOHN GARDINER
. It is false.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Transported for Seven Years .

976.
CHARLES PROUTINGS
was indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of April , 7 books, value 4s. 6d. , the goods of
John Francis Tappin
and
William Cousans
.

WILLIAM COUSANS
, I am in partnership with John Francis Tappin; we are booksellers
, and live in High-street, Marylebone
. On the 5th of April the constable came to our house, and brought some books, which I knew- we have a stall-board in front of our house, on which I had placed, among other books, Guy's grammar that morning, about eight o'clock - the officer brought that and the other books about two o'clock; they had not been sold.

WILLIAM HUGHES. I am a Police-constable. I saw the prisoner in Queen-street, Edgware-read on the 5th of April - he had a parcel tied up in a handkerchief; I stopped him, and asked him what he had got - he said some books which he had bought of two boys in Paddington-street, and given 1s. 3d. for them - he was then about a quarter of a mile from the prosecutor's.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I knew nothing of their being stolen - I bought them of two boys for 1s. 3d.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Whipped and Discharged.

977.
MICHAEL MCLOUGHLIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of April , 1 half-crown, the money of
Mary Bruce
, from her person .

MARY BRUCE
. I live in the Almonry, Westminster. On the night of the 6th of April I met the prisoner coming up the passage into the Almonry - he asked me to go with him, but I would not; he then asked me to go and have some supper - we went to a cook-shop, in Tothill-street
; I sat down by him, and while I was sitting I felt his hand in my pocket - he said he had dropped his tobacco-box; I said I would pick it up for him - he then said he had it in his pocket; I came out of the cook-shop with him, and when I came out I missed a half-crown which I had in my pocket about half an hour before; I charged him with it - he said he had not got it; I had it in my pocket, wrapped up in a piece of paper, when I went into the cook-shop.

Prisoner. Q. Did you make any alarm in the shop? A. No; but I felt your hand in my pocket, and you took hold of my hand immediately - I told you I missed it when I got on the step; there was a hole in my pocket, but the paper could not get through it - the Policeman did not give me a half-crown in the watch-house to try it, and it went through.

EDWARD BARTHOLOMEW
. I am a labourer, and live in New-way, Westminster. On the night of Tuesday, the 5th, or rather on Wednesday morning, the 6th of April, I saw the prisoner being taken to the watch-house - I followed him, and saw him put his hand up as if he was going to put it into his waistcoat pocket; I then saw his hand drop, and saw this paper laying twisted up on the ground - I went up to the watch-house, and heard the charge - the prisoner was then set at liberty; I was going back, and the prisoner came to near the same place where I had seen the paper lay - he seemed to be looking about for something, or I should not have thought of looking; I then looked, and found this paper, with half a crown in it - this was in about seven or eight minutes after I first saw it.

Prisoner. I was taken to the watch-house, and this man followed - what money I had about me, which was some copper, was returned to me; I stripped, dressed again, and as I was going away this man stooped down, and said, "I have picked up half a crown;" I was then taken back - the Policeman gave her a half-crown, and it fell through a hole in her pocket - it was a French pocket, in front of her apron; Bartholomew swore he saw me put my hand into my pocket.

EDWARD BARTHOLOMEW
. They did take down that you put your hand into your pocket, but I put up my finger, and said, "No, Sir;" I repeated what I had said, that I saw your hand as if you had put your hand into your pocket, but I saw nothing drop - I saw the paper on the ground; I never saw the prosecutrix till that evening; I heard of the charge as I sat in my own house - I went out, and followed him to the watch-house.

Prisoner. I met this girl of the town; she wanted the to go home and sleep with her; I said I had a wife and three children - there was a woman in company with her in the shop, who said, "I know him to be married, so go about your business."

JOHN FREDERICK
BOHM. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, and found 6 1/2d. in copper, which was given him again; he was then set at liberty, and I took him again.
JURY. Q. Did you try whether a half-crown would go through a hole in her pocket? A. Yes, I tried it; it would go through with squeezing, but not in the paper.

MARY BRUCE
. The paper was like that, and I folded it in that way - there was a little mustard on it.
Prisoner's Defence. She is a girl who would swear any thing; I know nothing of her, but giving her a basin of soup - when she found I would not go with her, she gave charge of me.

GUILTY . Aged 35. -
Transported for Seven Years .

978.
JOHN DENNIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of March , 2 bottles, value 8s., and 1 glass knob, value 8s. , the goods of
Thomas Simmons
.

ALFRED SMITH
. I am shopman to Mr. Thomas Simmons, a glass-man, who lives in Brownlow-street. On the 31st of March I was coming from the back part of the shop, and saw the prisoner in front of the counter - he took up a parcel; I asked him what he wanted, and he told me a gentleman had sent that parcel from Holborn - I said No, it was one I had put on the counter; his breast looked bulky, and I stepped to the door to look for an officer - I turned round, and saw the prisoner placing these bottles and this chandelier knob on the counter, but I did not see from what part of his person he produced them; the constable came in in about half an hour, and I gave the prisoner into custody - these are the bottles and the knob; they are Mr. Simmons' property - there were some odd drops, as patterns in the parcel which he took up; I had received it a short time before, from an out-door workman - these bottles had been on a shelf above the counter, and the knob on a shelf by the side of the counter.
Prisoner. Q. Did you see me put them from my person? A. Yes, I did.

GEORGE JOHN
BESTIAUX. I am a Police-constable. The prisoner was placed in my custody.
Prisoner's Defence. I deny ever having them in my possession.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 18.

Recommended to Mercy by the Jury. -
Confined 1 Month .

979.
ANN BUNKER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of April , 2 pairs of leather soles, value 2s., and 3 pairs of half-soles, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
William Thomas Binckes
.

WILLIAM THOMAS BINCKES
. I am a leather-seller , and live in Great Newport-street, Soho
. On the night of the 5th of April the prisoner came into my shop, a little after eight o'clock, and asked to look at some grained leather, which I put on the counter; I then left the shop, and went into a private passage, from whence I could watch her - I saw her put four pieces of leather into her pocket; I sent my girl for an officer to take her as she went from the shop - he took her; she dropped two pieces of leather, and then another piece; he then searched her, and found three pairs of soles on her - I have known her four or five years; her husband is always laid up sick, and she has three children.

GREGORY COLE DUDLEY
. I am a Police-officer. On the night of the 5th of April I took the prisoner about six yards from the prosecutor's door - she dropped two pieces of leather from under her cloak; the prosecutor took them up - I took her farther, and she dropped another piece of sole leather - I then took her into a door-way, and examined her; I found these three pieces of leather wrapped up in her gown.
Prisoner. I took it in a mistake.

GUILTY . Aged 42. -
Confined Three Months .

980.
WALTER BRETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of April , 3 seals, value 30s.; 3 rings, value 30s., and 1 bevil, value 3s. , the goods of
John Brett
.
The prosecutor did not appear NOT GUILTY .

981.
JAMES ASHTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of March , 1 bonnet, value 12s. , the goods of
Thomas Cox
.

SARAH COX
. I am the wife of Thomas Cox, a labourer - we live in Golden-lane
. I had a bonnet in a cupboard in one of my rooms on the 21st of March - it was safe about eleven o'clock, and I missed it between eleven and twelve o'clock - this is it; I saw Elizabeth Bulmer with it in her hand last Monday week.

ELIZABETH BULMER
. I live in Milton-street, and am the wife of John Bulmer, a bricklayer. On the 21st of March I was in Chapel-street, and saw the prisoner there, between twelve and one o'clock - it is a good step from the prosecutor's; he asked me to buy a bonnet - I said I did not want one; he asked where I lived - I showed him over the way; he came to my house, and brought this bonnet - he asked me 4s. for it; I agreed to give him 3s. - I paid him 1s. 6d. then, and 1s. 6d. the next day; this is the bonnet - I gave it to the officer.

JOHN COHEN
. I am Bulmer's brother-in-law. I saw this bargaining about the bonnet when I went home to dinner - the prisoner was sitting in a chair in my room, with it in his hand; and while I was eating my dinner, in came my sister, and bought it of him for 3s.

WILLIAM BALLARD
. I am a Police-officer. I received the bonnet from Bulmer - she had it on her head, and the prosecutor claimed it.

JOHN SMITH
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, in Golden-lane, where his father keeps a shop - he mentioned the name of some person who he bought it of, but we could not find him.
Prisoner's Defence. I met a young man I knew that day, and he asked me if I knew any lady who wanted to buy a bonnet - I sold it for him.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Confined Six Months .

982.
MARIA NEEDHAM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of March , 8 shirts, value 30s.; 2 sheets, value 4s.; 2 table-cloths, value 5s., and 1 handkerchief, value 6d., the goods of
James Peckett
; and 1 gown, value 2s.; 1 shift, value 1s. 6d., and 1 night-gown, value 1s. , the goods of
Mary Jenkins
.

THOMAS HOBBS KING
. I am a Police-officer. On the night of the 29th of March I stopped the prisoner in Maiden-lane, Islington, at half-past nine o'clock - I saw her before I stopped her, in company with a young man, who had this bundle under his arm; he gave it to the prisoner, and they separated - she came on, and he staid in the road; they had not seen me or Harris, who was with me - the prisoner then came on, and as soon as she got sight of me, she dropped the bundle; the young man ran across the fields - this is the bundle, it contains the articles stated; they were wet when I took them.

ALFRED HARRIS
. I am a Police-constable. I was with King, and took up the bundle - the prisoner said she knew nothing of it, and that she was one hundred yards from it, but she was not more than five yards from it - she said she knew nothing of the young man; but the next morning she said she was in company with him, and had some conversation with him about some money for some shoes - he goes by the name of Daddy Lee - that was the name she expressed.

JAMES PECKETT
. I live in White Conduit-grove, Islington
. This bundle contains eight shirts belonging to me, two table-cloths, and the other articles stated - they are all mine, except what are my servants', Mary Jenkins; here is a gown, a shift, and night-gown of hers - they were all hanging in the yard behind my house on the evening of the 29th of March, and were missed at a quarter before nine o'clock - I know nothing of the prisoner.
T. H. KING re-examined. Q. How far from the prosecutor's did you stop the prisoner? A.About three quarters of a mile - it was about half-past nine o'clock.
Prisoner's Defence. I was coming down Maiden-lane, and a young man asked me to hold a bundle - directly I took it he ran away.
T. H. KING. No, they were talking together, and she walked ten or fifteen yards before she caught sight of us; there were three more she impeached - the man has absconded ever since.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .

983.
JOSEPH MOORE
was indicted for
stealing, onthe 31st of March , 2 pairs of gaiters, value 2s. 6d.; 24 buttons, value 1s., and 1 ball of silk twist, value 2s. , the goods of
William Gansden
.

GEORGE DOSSON
. I am a Police-constable. On Thursday evening, the 31st of March, I was in Chiswell-street; I saw the prisoner about twenty minutes after eight o'clock in the evening, with something bulky in his jacket - I followed him a few paces, and asked what he had there; he said Nothing, but I opened his jacket and found the property - I was taking him to the prosecutor, on suspicion, and he said, "If you will let me go this time I will never do the like again."

FRANCES GANSDEN
. I am the daughter of
William Gansden
- he lives in Beech-street
, and is a tailor - I am eleven years of age. On Thursday night, the 31st of March, between eight and nine o'clock, I was in my father's shop and saw the prisoner and another boy come in- the other boy asked me the price of some pearl buttons, which were in the window - I sent my sister to ask my father; she came back and said they were 1s. a dozen - the boy looked at them, and said they were flat, not round, and he would tell his mother the price - they then went out, and in ten minutes the officer came - I looked into the window and missed the parcel of pearl buttons - I did not miss the garters - the buttons had been safe till they came in, and the officer brought them back.

WILLIAM GANSDEN
. These gaiters are mine; one pair has a ticket on them of my writing - I know I had such buttons as these, and this is the very number that was missed out of the gross - my house is about seven doors from where he was taken.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 15.

Recommended to Mercy by the Jury -
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

984.
JOHN JOHNSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of March , 1 stove, value 14s. , the goods of
Stephen Horncastle Geldard
.

STEPHEN HORNCASTLE GELDARD
. I live in Pullen's-row, Chelsea - I have the care of a house called Ranelagh cottage
; it is unoccupied; there are stoves and other fixtures in it. I was there about twelve o'clock in the day on the 5th of March; I fastened the doors when I left; I received some information in about half an hour, and returned; I looked through the parlour window, and saw the prisoner in the parlour, with a stove in his hand; I put the key into the lock, and heard a bolt-shot on the other side - I broke a pane of glass, unfastened the window, and got in; I saw him going out at the back door; he went down the garden - some persons met him, and he jumped into the common sewer; I followed him; he got out, went over a wall, and across a nursery-ground - he was afterwards taken - the stove had been taken out of its place, and set behind the parlour door; I had lost a grate from the same house on the Saturday before - a key was given to me by one of the witnesses, which opened the door very easily.

JAMES CLARK
. I am a Police-officer. I received the prisoner about twelve o'clock in the morning of the 5th of March; I found a pad of rags on his shoulder, under his coat.

CHARLES KIDD
. I live in Hertford-street. On the 5th of March I was passing the Five-fields, and saw the prisoner running; I stopped him, and said, "My friend, where are you running? what is all this hue and cry?" he said, "It is only a parcel of boys hunting me" - I said, "It is very curions, wait till they come up;" he said,"Oh! no, let me go" - I said No! and stopped him; he threw out his right hand, and threw away a key - I pointed out the place where it was thrown.

EDWARD ROSER
. I live in Ebury-square, Pimlico - I am a carrier. On the 5th of March I was in Union-street, I saw the prisoner come running down the street, and some persons were calling Stop theif! I saw the prisoner stopped by a person a few yards from me; I saw him throw something away - I took it up, and it was this key.
MR. GELDARD. This key will open the room door. and I found this piece of iron in the passage just by the back door - I had lost eight stoves before.

JAMES CLARK
. I saw the prisoner go into the sewer, up to his knees.

Prisoner's Defence. I was going down the lane, and was taken had in my inside; I got over the rails, and heard a cry of Stop thief! I crossed the ditch, and went into the privy; I then got over a wall into the road, and a person stopped me, but I can take my solemn oath I threw nothing out of my hand - I never was in the house.

GUILTY . Aged 23. -
Transported for Seven Years .

985.
JAMES HEATH
and
JOHN BAILES
were indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of February , 3 pairs of shoes, value 3s., and 1 brush, value 6d. , the goods of
John Dickenson
.

BENJAMIN FOSTER
. I live in Paradise-street, St. Luke's, and am a labourer. On the 22nd of February I was coming up Paradise-place, about three o'clock; I saw three lads; the prisoners were two of them; they were standing altogether - Heath had some shoes in the bosom of his coat; I saw the heels of them sticking out; I went to the prosecutor's shop, which is in Tabernacle-walk
, close by, and spoke to his wife; she said there were three pairs of shoes gone - Mr. Dickenson came up, and he got me to go with him in pursuit of the boys, who had all run away; I came up to the prisoners in Pitfield-street - the prosecutor and the Police-officer had then secured them.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You did not see Heath do any thing? A. No - the boy who is not in custody was the oldest; Heath did not say the other gave them to him to hold - he seemed frightened; we lost sight of the other all at once.

ROBERT RODMAN
. I was servant to Mr. Woodward, a cabinet-maker, who lives in Old-street-road. On the 22nd of February I was standing at his door, and saw the two prisoners run by - Heath threw three pairs of shoes and a bottle-brush at me; they were running by as fast as they could - I took the shoes and brush to the back of the shop, placed them under one of the tables, and the Police-officer came and had them.
Cross-examined. Q.Did he not tell you he was tired of them, and that another gentleman gave them to him? A. No, he did not say where he got them.

GEORGE DICKENSON
. I am a broker - I live in Tabernacle-walk. On the 22nd of February , in consequence of information from Foster and my wife, I went in pursuit of some boys to Old-street-road - I got sight of the two prisoners and another , going towards Shoreditch ; they turned down a street , then across Hoxton-market, and out by Hoxton new church - I went on to Pitfield-street, came up with the prisoners in Royal Oak-walk, and took them; these are my shoes and brush - I had not been out of the shop a quarter of an hour .

Cross-examined. Q. I suppose you have some mark on them? A. I can swear to the shoes, by this break in the grain of one - they hung on the door; a person standing on the steps might take them without going into the shop.

JOHN OWEN
. I am a Police-constable. I saw the prisoners in Pitfield-street, and assisted in taking them at the top of the court; I received the shoes and brush from Rodman, tied together as they are now .
Bailes' Defence. We were going along, and saw some boys with the shoes and brush - we heard a cry of Stop thief! they ran and we ran .
Heath's Defence. I never saw the shoes; I was going for some potatoes .
The prisoners received a good character.

HEATH -
GUILTY . Aged 13.

BAILES -
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor and Jury.
Whipped and Discharged .

986.
JOHN DAVIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of March , 1 African dress robe, value 3l. , the goods of
Maria Lardner
.

MARIA LARDNER
. I live in Acre-cottage, Camden-town
, and am a widow . The prisoner was in my son's service; he is an officer in the Second West India Regiment - in September last my son and the prisoner left my house to go abroad, but in a few days the ship got leaky, and returned to Margate; my son went to an hotel, the prisoner left him, and came back to my house - he continued there till the 24th of March, when I sent him away , and when he was gone I missed the robe of an African chief, which my son had brought from abroad, and made me a present of - I went to the house of
Martha Baggs
, and got the robe from her.

GEORGE BROWN
. I am a Police-constable. I took the prisoner in Pratt-street, on the 24th of March; I told him I took him on suspicion of stealing this dress - he said his mistress gave it him to put on his bed, to keep him warm ;
Martha Baggs
is not here .

COURT to MRS. LARDNER. Q. Do you know whether it was used on the prisoner's bed? A. He complained of being cold (as they are always very chilly), and wished to have more clothes - I think he had this on his bed; he has been always robbing me.
NOT GUILTY .
